reviewText:
Unlike Call of Duty - Black Ops II, this actually gets Afghanistan right. The setting looks like the mountains I flew over and the valley I rucked in. It looks like Afghanistan, it sounds like Afghanistan, and despite the game-isms, does a good job of telling the story.  Little things stand out to me - the visible selector switch from semi to full, the relatively realistic weapons models, the radio chatter and dialogue - as authentic. There are some reality breakers, like a general in a suit during cutscenes or the wrong time period highspeed gofast gear on dudes in a game set in 2001, but I can put them aside and enjoy the atmosphere.

The campaign isn't going to appeal to everyone. It's shorter than some, and it's not full of Michael Bay explosions like the Call of Duty series (which I also own). What makes the single player shine is that it's based on real events. The set pieces (vehicle sections, stand-and-fights) are well presented, and logically flow with the game. There's a sense of being part of a larger picture with the radio chatter between AFOs Neptune and Wolfpack and their boss ('Jimmy,' or COL Drucker in the cutscenes). Your actions make sense, and several times throughout the game you'll see the other AFO doing their part of the missions.

It's worth picking up, on sale or full price, and getting a solid play through. If you want to see a more realistic shooter than the Call of Duty series with a story grounded in actual events, this is the one. This is probably the most under-appreciated military shooter in recent memory for me, purely as an on-the-rails gut wrench adrenaline ride (the downhill scramble to the chopper and the stand-your-ground sequences in particular). Yeah, there's hand-holding, but it the game it makes sense. No one plays rambo in real life, because that's how you die.

reviewText:
This Medal of Honor game, is the thirteenth in the series as a whole. It was released in October 2010 on PC and both consoles. This it the first of the Medal of Honor games to not take place during World War II, this time we are in Afghanistan.

Game play is almost identical to other FPS games of this type. It has a very hand holding feel to it, you are part of a squad of elite soldiers, and you could actually just sit back and let them do the killing if you were that was inclined. You have to follow a linear path on each level and it offers only one way of getting there. You take part in ground missions, sniper missions and Apache gunner missions throughout the single player campaign. All of the guns feel  very much the same, and for some reason, and they make a shotgun the weakest weapon ever... A couple of the missions are based on stealth style gameplay, which is something I am really starting to get into, and it does that side of things very well. It offers something new to see in a generic FPS game. The regular run and gun gameplay is very repetitive in this Medal of Honor title.

This game was made using a very heavily modified Unreal Engine 3.I was playing Medal of Honor on 4k resolution, and it looks amazing. The character models are probably my favorite thing about this game when on the topic of graphics. I got a good few screenshots of just how lifelike their faces looked, it took me by quite a surprise if I am honest.  Some of the textures are a bit low quality, but they only seem to be in places where you aren't really expected to look, but it was a shame to see it since it did kind of ruin the immersion for me when the rest of the game looked so good.

The plot takes place in 2001, during the opening days of the invasion of Afghanistan. Whilst it has a very generic, america beats everyone feel to it, I did quite enjoy the story; it has some good character development and interesting plot points. It is certainly a better story than most of the CODs.

Medal of Honor offers no difficulty at all, you are hand held throughout the whole game by the rest of the squad and I don't think I died even once whilst playing. Some of the more challenging missions would be when you are playing the sniper missions, because you have to find enemies in a open landscape, and they are camouflaged to the high heavens and makes it practically impossible to spot them.

All of the levels in Medal of Honor are very linear; you are essentially going from A to B and you cannot divert off the track in anyway. You have to follow your squad leader and that is it. This leaves little opportunity for you to explore the map, and even if you did, there is not much to find anyway. Mostly empty houses with nothing interactive or remotely interesting in anyway.

The single player mode took me just about five hours to complete; and there is no reason at all for you to play it through more than once, yes you can ramp up the difficulty, but honestly, the harder modes are just as easy. Oh and the multiplayer, I wasn't even able to get into a match since the community is dead. There are very little games, and the ones I could find, were riddled with hackers and aim bots making it pointless even to pick this game up for the multiplayer.

Technically, I didn't have any problems. I was able to play at 60+ FPS on 4k resolutions all the time. You will need v-sync on but this doesn't effect your frames like other games. There is a good amount of options in the menus to customize the graphics and keybindings too.

In summary; I don't think I can recommend Medal of Honor for full price, the £14,99 price tag for what is essentially a single player game that lasts about five hours cannot be justified in anyway. If the multiplayer scene was still active I would at least recommend it purely based on that, but it isn't.  I would say if you can get this game for less than £4,99, then pick it up, but not for a penny more.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
Overall this is a great single player experience - the missions themselves are immersive and the environments - mountainous terrain interspersed with villages makes for a fresh and good air battle with helicopters.
Be prepared for a short single player experience, so feel free to drag it out and not sprint the whole way through the game. My only criticism is of the General (Flag I think) 's character. The meddling top brass who doesn't know that he's sacrificing his men while not listening to those with their boots on the ground has been done, and adds no real depth to the game other than having an excuse to play as an army ranger.

Advantages of the game:Action packed, fast paced and exciting singleplayer campaign.
Great shooting, some moments of stealth interwined as well.
Good controls for PC, which is not always the case for a lot of games released these days.
Decent graphics.
Story is acceptable, but the end is a little sad.
Multiplayer is good and has more action than singleplayer.

reviewText:
This is my opinion of Medal Of Honor
Aspect        Rating                Story        6.5                Graphics        7.5                Sound        9.0                Gameplay        6.5                Overall        7.4    Scores are out of 10. Overall score is an average

This was the first Medal Of Hornor game that I have played. Though it may be tempting to look at its flaws and dismiss Medal of Honor as inferior to its competitors, there is a lot to enjoy here. The campaign has its shortcomings, but its unique sense of scope and well-orchestrated pacing make it an enjoyably cohesive adventure. Medal of Honor doesn't set any new standards for the genre, but it delivers a lot of entertainment and excitement if you're looking to add a splash of realism to your first-person shooting.

I wouldnt recommend this game at full price, but when on sale, be sure to pick up your copy of Medal of Honor.

AI is somewhere between brain dead and acceptable. Enemies will take cover and shoot back, but that's about it. Gunplay is mildly immersive, though your teammates are more of an annoyance than help.

Good for a lazy afternoon and for less than $5. Also, ♥♥♥♥ EA.

reviewText:
Note: the following review covers only the single player campaign.

There was a point in time when Medal of Honor was a series that mattered. A franchise born in a time where WWII shooters were still hot and Allied Assault was blowing players and its competition away. But between then and now bolt action rifles and beach stormings have fallen out of fashion, most of the people who made Medal of Honor a respected name among shooters have long since left for other studios, and 2010’s reboot (for lack of a more appropriate term) is left doing the same thing so many other games were a decade or so ago when the series was first kicking off: attempting to ape its peers in the hope of grabbing a slice of the pie.

Today’s analogical pastry is the impossibly large Call of Duty, which along with its innovations in campaign structures and online play brought itself out of the early 20th century and into modern day. Naturally every other military shooter has followed suit, but Medal of Honor is perhaps the first to really attempt to ground itself in the ongoing conflicts happening in the middle east, a decision that could have given its campaign meaning outside of itself and showcased to its players the very real horrors raging on in Afghanistan which somehow still feel so distant.

Instead we end up with exactly what you’d expect from a modern military shooter, except coming along with the added baggage of playing off actual current events, which for all of developer Danger Close’s intentions has only managed to turn the game into a giant mess. It’s not that I expected Medal of Honor to provide any meaningful commentary on the scenarios its portraying, but by marrying its summer action movie mentality to a war that’s still raging and killing thousands it trivializes the losses of American soldiers and innocent Afghans for mindless entertainment.

Medal of Honor is happy to proclaim itself as being “real” only so far as it can manage to fit in a blockbuster sequence of set pieces and explosions, showing you how horrible the things its replicating are one second while reveling in gory headshots and idiotic “bro-speak” the next. It feels emotionally manipulative and tasteless, unwilling to commit to being anything but a dumb action game with as little nuance in presenting its subject matter as that usually entails.

And what an unbelievably dumb game Medal of Honor is. Below its terribly handled premise, incoherent plot, and attempts at “gritty realism”, there’s a game that’s terrified of letting you play it. It funnels you through levels with gratuitous levels of restriction, placing invisible walls everywhere so as to always be entirely in control of where you are and where you can go even if it intends to let you there later. You move when it tells you to, shoot where it points you, watch the often malfunctioning scripted sequences sometimes when it makes you, and participate in its series of strict directions because that’s all you can do.

Medal of Honor is so obsessed with being in control that I began to ask why I was even there at all. The game clearly didn’t want me there, as I became one more thing needing to be kept on a leash, in case I potentially walk too far ahead and break another scripting trigger or stumble into an area before it’s had time to spawn its enemies, and I didn’t want to be there because the lack of any player agency made it feel like I was watching a very dull movie that I had to keep moving forward.

But it’s probably the incompetency with which the game hides any of this that’s the most insulting. There’s never any question that you’re being moved through egregiously linear environments, shooting enemies with zero tactical awareness that pop up like target dummies with guns that never feel right. The game presents itself entirely as it is, as if it hasn’t even enough pride to try and hide its mind numbing tediousness and genericism; to try and pretend it wasn’t plopped out in the hopes of catching hold of Call of Duty’s momentum because it hasn’t a single original idea left for itself. In a way I kind of appreciate this sort of honesty, if only because it’s the only bit of sincerity the game ever shows.

reviewText: Medal of Honor is a First-Person shooter, and also the thirteenth game in the series, taking place in Afghanistan, instead of the previous titles which took place during The Second World War. Released in 2010, Medal of Honor, has you conducting hostage rescues, and raiding hideouts, while navigating through dangerous territories filled with insurgents. IED's and realistic ambushes put you in the crosshairs and make you feel like you are actually in the firefights. The realism we've come to expect from the Medal of Honor series does not disappoint.\n\nYou play the game as one of several different characters throughout the missions, from Navy Seals to Army Rangers. The story takes place beginning in 2001 during the beginning of the Afghanistan invasion. The game also has multiplayer mode, which features three different classes; Rifleman, Special Operations, and Snipers. An interesting title, one I would recommend to anyone who doesn't have PTSD, as the realistic quality and content could be psychologically damaging.

reviewText:
If you have watched any number of genuine helmet cam war videos, you will appreciate the highly realistic portrayal of tactics.
This is not a corridor shooter. It is a roleplaying game best enjoyed when you immerse yourself in your role and play it out like the real soldiers.
The gameplay settings are pleasantly variable - sniping, sneaking, assault, and vehicle levels with the respective operator groups. This includes the actual equipment each of them uses and their expectable sound and power of effect.
This is a chiseled out and fact-checked shooter I would definitely recommend any day.

ReviewMedal of Honor 2010 was a pretty decent campaign blaster. It's extremely set-piece, but the guns have a percussive sound and an authority. Action is frenetic. It's optimized to the level that if you melee but miss, you can hold the button to draw your pistol instead and blast a guy, operator style. There's a lot of attention to detail and realism, as well as an incredible atmosphere riding ATVs through the desert, eliminating AQ with suppressed rifles and takedowns, then calling in dazzling close air support.

But it really isn't a big deal for any one reason. It isn't a Call of Duty 4 with tons of innovative gameplay. Just a decent story, realistic and well-paced. Too short, a bit too linear and too much perspective changing. Better than any of the Battlefield games that came after it, and the craptastic Warfighter game. The multiplayer, being essentially Bad Company 2 without any actual depth, isn't really worth comment.

reviewText:
!Single Player Only Review!

It was supposed to be the game that would break Activision's CoD empire, it was supposed to be the game that would reestablish the once great Meda of Honor name. Now, it's a game that will no-one remember and the game that fell short in every aspect it could have.

The story of MoH itself is uninteresting, undercooked and short. The game can be finished in a mere 5 hours on normal settings, without any, and I mean ANY replay value. There aren't any collectibles, multiple paths or story elements that would encourage the player to start the game all over again. Once you have finished it semi-frustrated there is no going back to it. Frustration is a concept that will many of us have to face in MoH. The super-linear nature of the discourages any way of alternate pathfinding. To put it simple, if you don't do what the game says you to do, you're dead. Don't try to be a hero, as you always have to follow instructions to survive. If you are told to hold position, don't try to peek above the wall, because you are getting shot. If you are told to run or retreat don't try to stay and hold off the enemy as they will kill you...sometimes even behind cover.

Not is all bad about the game however. Two things stand out the most. The graphics are beautiful even on medium settings. Water, rocks, buildings and shadows look astonishing. The other thing where you have to give credit to the creators is trying to maintain authenticity. Places, soldiers, the way they talk to each other, situations all feel real to a person who is inexperienced in war situations. The game itself takes place in Afghanistan and it's plot is loosely based on the Operation Anaconda where US soldiers tried to destroy Taliban forces back in '02.

I can honestly say that I haven't seen a game that would want YOU to rush through it's single player mode. This game does. For one thing its ultra short. Experienced player can finish it in 4 to 5 hours easily, and checkpoints are so frequent that even if you happen to die, you won't be set back for more than 2 minutes of your progress. Literally, a level starts with an in-game cinematic and a shepherd is taken down silently by your fellow soldier, and boom checkpoint. Sometimes it feels like the game throws you a CP every time you reload you weapon. The level design is also horrible, excluding the first few stages, on all of the levels there is 1 hard point where you are so overwhelmed that you will die 3-10 times in 5 minutes. Up until that point and even after that there is little to no resistance. To put it gently, it's unbalanced.

When you get frustrated (and you'll get) by the SP you can try the Tier1 mode, which is unlocked once you've completed the SP on any difficulty. Basically, Tier1 is the same as the SP just with some gameplay tweaks, e.g. difficulty is set to hard and you have no restarts. Once you die, you have to start over again. There is a time limit in each level that you have to beat, and headshots will freeze the timer for a couple of seconds. To conserve time there aren't any cutscenes either. This mode really is for hardcore MoH players and I doubt that any of the one-timers will enjoy it.

Rating: 47/100; Replay Value: 1/5; To Beat: 5 hours; Played on: normal.

reviewText:
If you manage to get this game for very low price, it's worth trying out.
Well-optimised, not too hardware-demanding, runs on max settings without any hiccups, with good graphics.

The singleplayer is good:
I like the Afghanistan and military atmosphere. Audio is very good, graphics are beautiful and sharp. Character animations are somewhat good.
The story is short, characters are noticable but rather character-less (bearded guy with a cap).
There's no customisation, no ranks and no collectibles, in singleplayer. The cover system is working great.
But as said, it's good - I installed this game because I felt like playing a shooter, taking place in Afghanistan (or
something with lot of sand) and I got just what I needed.

The singleplayer deserves a 7/10 rank, not bad. Good atmosphere and fun combat.




The multiplayer is extremly mediocre. Very few players still play, but you find one-two full servers every now-and-then.
While singleplayer is running on beautiful and polished Unreal Engine, the multiplayer is powered by a watered-down Frostbite engine. They removed cover mechanics, character animations suck, detection of hits is pretty damn bad, maps are too small and most of killing is ruthless spawntrapping. Movement is extremly sloppy and bulky, there are problems with delay (even if your ping is low).
At least, I didn't encounter any blatant cheating, at least something.
The unlock system is decent. Also weapon customisation. There are three classes, each one has unique equipment for both faction (Taliban and US).
Rarely, you get a good match with the right type of players, in that case the multiplayer is great. But as said - very rarely.

Multiplayer deserves the ranking of around 5/10, not sure.
It mainly suffers from the engine, removal of features (comparing to singleplayer) and strange map and encounter design.

reviewText:
Medal of Honor (Played on the highest difficulty).

Positives:

+ Action packed, fast paced and exciting singleplayer campaign.
+ Great shooting, some moments of stealth interwined as well.
+ Good controls for PC, which is not always the case for a lot of games released these days.
+ Decent graphics.
+ Story is acceptable, nothing incredible though.

Negatives:

- Short singleplayer campaign, takes around 7-8 hours to finish on the hardest difficulty setting.
- Very linear, you'll progress from one mission to the next with restrictive environments. No exploration or side missions.
- Story, while reasonable, could improve greatly and lift the score for this game.
- Multiplayer is literally full of young kids. No realism or authenticity here, the guns are awkward to use, the maps unimaginative and it is plagued by the typical problems with multiplayer, like spawn camping. As a whole, it's a boring multiplayer experience.

Overall Score: 7/10

Medal of Honor is a fun singleplayer game and that's probably all you need to know to buy it. Sure, it doesn't last long, but those 7-8 hours are good. Multiplayer does suck, so if you're purchasing for that reason alone, I'd say avoid.

Pick it up on sale for 1-2 dollars like I did, and it will be well worth it.

reviewText:
I have no idea why I'm rating this as positive, since this game has so many flaws it's incredible. It has some nice pros but it is FAR out weighed by its cons.

Pros :

-Some of the best 2010 graphics. Still competes with todays graphics.
-Solid Sound ( No doubt the strong in this game, coming in with an overal 9.5-10/10 IMO )
-Decent singleplayer storyline
-Vehicles ( Very VERY few )
-Fairly well optimized
-Doesnt require a high spec rig
-Cheap
-Doesn't require Origin
-Not buggy
-Weapon customization ( Barely any, but still )
-Killstreaks
-Anticheat ( Not the best but it gets the job done )
-Not alot hackers ( due to the fact that most servers are dedicated with admins kicking )
-The perfect niche between Call of Duty and Battlefield

Cons:

-Some of the worst map design I've seen in a while. Yes ; The maps are worse then Call of Duty maps.
-Lack of killstreaks ( It is a good thing that the game has them; but the few ones it has are EXTREMLY similiar. )
-12 Year old community who hackusate everyone on the team for aimbotting or kids who ♥♥♥♥ your mom.
-Absoulutely horrendous spawns / spawn system. This NEEDS to be revamped.
-Did I mention the maps?
-Nade spam
-Rocket spam ( 3/4 of my deaths at the end of the game are to rockets and or nades alone. This NEEDS to be fixed. )
-Dying playerbase ( There are a couple servers everyday so that is good / nice, however most will be high ping since there's so few.
-9/10 servers will be high ping due to the fact that there are so few servers and the chances of ya living close are so slim
-The nade spam makes Call of Duty look like a good game
-Crappy looking UI
-Lack of gun diversity
-Crap gun customization
-Little to no vehicles.
-It's a little grindy.
-Few maps
-No medic / ammo classes like in Battlefield
-Few gamemodes
-The worst netcode I've ever seen in my life. If you thought Battlefield 4 has a rough release, youre in for a treat. This netcode is easily twice as bad. Imagine Battlefield 4's netcode on release with 1500 Ping... This is it. On top of that, you will usally get 50-200 MS ping per server.

The reason why this game is recommended by me is because it's so cheap it's worth a buy; IF you manage to find a copy under 10$. Personally, I got a copy for 0.98 $ and I would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if I got it for 1.98$
However, for 0.98$, it is worth every single penny for all the times you die due to ♥♥♥♥ netcode, high ping, terrible map design, nade spam, rocket spam, by the same two guns the game offers, and due to ridiculous killstreaks.
If you are into Call of Duty and or Battlefield and want to try something different this is a must buy.

reviewText:
The singleplayer campaign is not like in any other shooters. I find it realistic and engaging, the atmosphere is perfect and the dialogues between your mates are even better. For the first time I actually felt like a soldier thrown into the middle of a batlefield. You really have to immerse yourself in a role, trust your teammates and rely on them. And they have to do that too. The emphasis is put on tactics. We get to play three individuals which together combined make a whole decent story.
One thing that particularly annoyed me were buggy checkpoints. Sometimes I had to restart the mission to continue the game.

Overall, 7/10

reviewText: Medal of Honor™ is the best 1st person shooter (modern warfare combat) you can get your hands on. DICE has done a great job with this title back in 2010. Both single-player and multi-player components are intense and this is one of the few titles that can be proud of being a realistic and tough combat simulator. Take sides and fight as a Tier 1 US operator or a taliban force in Afganistan. Bring your skills with you because Medal of Honor™ will be an unforgettable experience. 10/10

reviewText:
Well,  this game left me with mixed feelings.

Besides the platitudinous plot about the good Americans and the bad middle easterns, the story was somewhat ambient. Sometimes gameplay was linear, though it don't mind it. What really bothered me, it was the scripted actions. Like, you can't progress the story if don't do some things like going to a specific spot or make a specific action.

Big minus imo, is the duration of the campaign, which is pretty small, so it's only value for money if you can get it on a sale, like 5-6 euro or something and only if you are medal of honor fan.

I liked very much voice actors and music background.

TL;DR
If you want to spend an evening, MoH is a nice way to do it, but get as cheaper you can on sale.

reviewText:
Medal of Honour is... Extremely Average

As a long time fan of the franchise, the chance of reboot is an exciting prospect, sadly it'll have to wait for another edition of this title to achieve its pontential. As an FPS it should have either had an incredible story, or incredible mechanics, Medal of Honour did a cracking job of not achieving either.

Lets not be solely negative, there is a few fantastic moments where the cinematography simply blows you away, but aside from those moments the showreel is lacking. The gameplay is solid, the campaign is short, the characters are not memorably at all but they do all have beards which is nice.

Cutting to the chase, unless you've played every Call of Duty and replayed your entire catalogue of games, it might be advisable to skip this title. If your intrigued and plan to purchase it, due to its mediocrity anywhere around £7 or less would be justifiable.

Notes
No Achievements, No Trading Cards, Controller Support

reviewText:
Story (Mild Spoilers)
Decent story. Shows the beginning of the invasion of Afghanistan by American troops. There's a political message about how bureaucrats in Washington don't know about the situation on the ground. It's minor and isn't heavy handed. But it feels......forced. Characters aren't compelling. There's nothing that makes you attached to them. And there's too many characters. 4 members of Navy Seals, then 4 members of Delta Force, another 4 members of the U.S Army Rangers and finally 4 crew members of Apache gunships. The first half of the game you play as Rabbit, a Navy Seal. Towards the end you switch between the rest of the groups. Story also got me confused when each of the members kept getting seperated from one another.
Overall 5/10

Gameplay
Average. Nothing special. Played kinda like CoD but felt better. The only thing that felt weird was sprinting and strafing. I can't quite put my finger on it. But it felt different and uncomfortable for some time. You run out of ammo a lot. But don't worry. You can borrow from your squad members. Also you don't tank enemy fire. Just a few hits and you're out. My favorite part of the game was using a SOFLAM to target enemy position for an AC-130. Felt really good watching the Taliban getting blown by various cannons. Another favorite moment was when your squad is pinned down by an overwhelming enemy force. And everyone of you LITERALLY runs out of ammo. No cover. No ammo. Enemies closing in from all three sides. Music crescending aaaaand..........play for yourself and find out.

reviewText:
It's okay, but I would not spend 20 bucks on it.

This is a 5 dollar shooter at best these days.

Still holds up nicely with beautiful landscapes and action scenes, the details are really great.  It is a shame they don't really let you explore at all though.  You are very much on a rail, closed off from anything you might wish to see... and often even guys holding guns you wish you could grab.  But the visual experience is nice even compared to recent releases IMO Some obvious aged limitations, but it does look very nice.

Sound is pretty good as well, decent enough I wanted to turn it up. Some gun sounds were kind of annoying, but they came out well even on some junk speakers I am forced to use lately, I am sure it would sound even better on an HD sound system.  No real audio experience complaints.

The story is totally boring to me, and I have played better rail shooters (Black comes to mind)  All of the limitations make me frustrated.  I was hoping for more of a multi-path shooter, with varied options for how to progress, not so.  The game is really just a quick action flick stuffed into a game.  At least it looks nice though.

The variety is nice, and this is way better than the old WW2 MoH games I played even back on what... PSX??  For what it is, it is well made.  You could do worse with your money, but there are much better shooters on steam for less than this at full price.

Honestly, it is not a bad game, but you won't be getting much from multiplayer, and the campaign is very short.

High budget quality... but only worth about 5 bucks on today's market.

reviewText:
Overall this is a great single player experience - the missions themselves are immersive and the environments - mountainous terrain interspersed with villages makes for a fresh and good air battle with helicopters.
Be prepared for a short single player experience, so feel free to drag it out and not sprint the whole way through the game. My only criticism is of the General (Flag I think) 's character. The meddling top brass who doesn't know that he's sacrificing his men while not listening to those with their boots on the ground has been done, and adds no real depth to the game other than having an excuse to play as an army ranger.

Advantages of the game:
Action packed, fast paced and exciting singleplayer campaign.
Great shooting, some moments of stealth interwined as well.
Good controls for PC, which is not always the case for a lot of games released these days.
Decent graphics.
Story is acceptable, but the end is a little sad.
Multiplayer is good and has more action than singleplayer.

reviewText:
The original  Medal of Honor was once a shining example of the FPS genre when it was released on the Playstation back in '99.

Shame the series hasn't really moved on much since then.

The gameplay is reminiscent of the COD: Modern Warfare series but without the above average scripting, awesome set-pieces and graphical pizazz that makes them enjoyable. The characters are the same cardboard cut-out grunts with plastic personalities that we've seen so many times before and gameplay revolves around clearing endless rooms of stereotypical 'Axis of Evil' bad guys.

Other than an excellent soundtrack, there's not much to recommend about Medal of Honor, whilst they have their own faults, Battlefield 4 or any of the Modern Warfare games will give you a much better experience in terms of graphics, gameplay and overall enjoyment.

I hope that the series makes a decent comeback sometime soon but this game isn't it.

reviewText: Medal of Honor is a fantastic addition to the string of modern warfare first-person shooters (FPS). The narrative, while brief, is a worthwhile experience that will leave you gaping for more. The graphics, gameplay and sounds will fully immerse you into the battlefields of Afghanistan given the game's detailed atmosphere. However, it should be noted that the singleplayer (SP) and multiplayer (MP) do not utilize the same game engine. While the SP uses a modified version of the Unreal Engine 3, the MP half uses DICE's Frostbite engine from the Battlefield series. Regardless, both the SP and the MP are worth a thorough playthrough. Keep in mind, that there are two DLC packs--Hot Zone" and "Clean Sweep"--that are available exclusively at EA's store and will be unlocked via your in-game persona using redeemable codes."

reviewText:
Medal of Honor throws you straight into the boots of a bad-♥♥♥ SEAL team, part of a 4-man group. As the story develops you not only get to play as only one single charachter, but many, in many different situations. This is undoubtedly the game's strong point - giving us as players, the chance to relate to, and understand and feel for other charachters as well, something that lacks greatly in other major AAA-titles.

Albeit the game takes on a different approach, contrasting their previous WW2-installments, this one, given its new take on the series, has its own share of pros and cons. As it's been mentioned, charachter development is top-notch, not to mention the awesome graphics (although the game was released back in 2014) which still looks good up to this day.

Drawbacks are unfortuneately the multiplayer part, with its numerous glitches, bugs, annoying controls and frankly, the lack of interesting content to give a real gameplay value, hence the bad score. Though, it's mentionworthy to say that they tried. And it's gotten even more polished in the sequel, Warfighter (not available on Steam). Another drawback is the feeling of doing the same mission, over and over, close to becoming annoying, but it never get's there (although pretty close). Last but not least, don't expect any long single-player campaign. It might be a short story, totalling around 4-5 hours. But you're into one hell of a ride, so it's by no means an easy" challenge
date: to say the least.\n\nI'll give this game 3 solid SEALS out of 5!"

reviewText:
I was bored one afternoon and decided to give Medal Of Honor a shot as I really enjoyed the Mutiplayer Beta but was in the mood for a single player game. I expected to spend 15 minutes playing and then go on to something else. What I found was something amazing.

MoH's single player is gritty and real. It embodies the harshness of the conflict and twines together the story of different squads interacting in the Afghan conflict perfectly. One moment you are waiting for evac and helicopters clear out the landing zone and then break off to hit another target - to which you transition to the next mission as that helicopter gunner.

The audio is visceral. I got shot at in a village and flinched when a metal wall next to me was peppered with bullets. I can't remember the last time I've reacted to a game in such a way - and that is a great thing.

MoH is a complete experience. I wish it lasted longer as I was able to complete the campaign in around 6 hours but it was worth every minute.

reviewText:
It's shocking to me how hyped this game was, and how terrible it is. This game is generic to the max. It's like they looked at Battlefield and Call of Duty, distilled the basic features out of them, and stripped out any unique or iconic gameplay. It really feels like CoD with less recoil and no soul.

I've tried both multiplayer and the campaign, but I'll be mostly reviewing the campaign. One thing I'll say about multiplayer - unless they've changed this, snipers start with no scopes, and you have to spend two hours getting spawn-killed and shooting one enemy per life to earn a crappy scope.

Again, the campaign is uber-generic. You are a soldier in a special ops unit. You get briefed on objectives you don't care about, and are thrown into some fighting. Your guns have no recoil. Occasionally you get a slow-motion event.

The missions aren't even put together well. There is a sniping mission where you work alongside a veteran sniper, an obvious attempt to copy the flashback mission in Modern Warfare, but executed so badly you'll be failing repeatedly while trying to figure out what he wants you to do. Everything has an extremely linear layout, but there are couple of places where it's still easy to get lost because the level doesn't flow well.

Several missions are extremely frustrating or repetitive, or both. One mission has you sniping enemy soldiers on a hill. They're pretty far away, in some trees, and you can't see jack ♥♥♥♥. You sit there and wait for your spotter to call out someone, try in vain to figure out where the target is, and then lose. But in the end you'll get it down because they keep spawning at a handful of locations.

The most memorable moment for me was a mission where I was halfway through the level, and a scripted event had us pinned down by enemy MGs. An ally ordered me to provide covering fire with my own light MG so they could move up. But... I dropped my MG at the beginning of the level for a different weapon. So I tried to provide covering fire with my AK. Over and over. Time after time, I wasted entire magazines, but my allies didn't do anything. I tried shooting the enemy gunners, which should have been easy because they weren't very far away, but they were invulnerable. I looked all around the area but there was no LMG available. Finally I realized I could try to pop a grenade in the MG nest. That took a few tries to do without dying, but when I finally got a grenade in there, I was rewarded with... nothing.

They seriously made a scripted event halfway through the level where you have to have an LMG to continue, but don't force you to keep the LMG from the beginning of the level and don't give you one when you need it. I had to replay the entire level with the LMG just to be able to pass that part.

♥♥♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design.

reviewText:
Download Size: Less than 9 gigabytes
Playtime: Less than 6 hours for single player

Medal of Honor (2010) was my intro to modern First Person Shooter games, so I go back and play it once in a while.  Despite the fact that the game plays nearly identically to the Call of Duty Modern Warfare games, Medal of Honor is actually from EA (makers of Battlefield). If you have this game, you probably got it as part of the Humble Origin Bundle from a year or so back (bunch of great games in that one). Like the Call of Duty games, MOH is split into Multiplayer and Single player installations, which means you can download just one or the other if you’re only planning to play through the campaign (like me). There is a separate Steam entry for each.

The story of MOH follows a couple of Navy Seal teams in Afghanistan trying to root out Al Qaida / Taliban soldiers, mostly taking place in the mountains. You also switch to playing a member of a squad of Army Rangers for a couple of missions, and see the war from a different perspective. MOH is very story driven, and since you’re almost always in a squad, you can count on the other members of your team to support you when you’re under heavy fire. However if you get shot enough you’ll die and reload the checkpoint. Your team doesn’t “revive” you like in some other squad based games (Payday, Left 4 Dead). Gameplay is very much like Call of Duty Modern Warfare where you’re supposed to do most of the heavy lifting while the rest of your team kind of picks off a few enemies occasionally and provides ammo.

MOH has the regenerating health system as expected in most modern first person shooters, with the screen edges turning red as you are taking damage and then clearing up if you don’t get shot for a few seconds. This means that a lot of the time you can risk making a run without cover and take some hits as long as you don’t die. You can also pick up the weapons of fallen enemies, though you should almost always keep your primary assault rifle (with the silencer when available).  An interesting gameplay element as mentioned above is that if you run low on ammo, you can always ask a computer controlled squad mate for more. I don’t remember this being available in many other first person games.

Pros:
+Pretty good graphics and engrossing story. If you like Call of Duty type shooter games, you should like MOH. I believe the game’s story is based on actual events.
+A lot of gameplay variety. You can occasionally control aerial bombardment (as an attack helicopter pilot) or heavy direct fire aircraft (blowing up stuff with big guns!). The sniper/stealth sections are fun as well.

Cons:
-The game is really short. It can take less than 5 hours to beat the campaign if you’ve played the game before. For a game this short it takes up a lot of hard drive space.
-There is at least 1 mission where it can be difficult to tell where you’re supposed to go. Your squad leader gives you an order and it isn’t immediately obvious what you’re supposed to do. Also, more than once I got stuck due to a game bug where an event didn’t trigger the way it was supposed to (marking a spot for air strike).

Overall Medal of Honor is a fun game to go through in a weekend, and get a feel for what highly trained combat soldiers have to do for a living. If you’ve seen the recent Mark Wahlberg movie “Lone Survivor” this game has a similar feel (elite soldiers surrounded by enemies).

Sequel info:
MOH Warfighter is exclusive to EA Origin (no Steam version). I got my copy as a physical DVD so I didn’t have to go through the process of downloading it through Origin.

Install size: Less than 20 gigabytes
Playtime: about 6 hours for single player

In Warfighter, you play a new member of the same group of Navy Seals as in the first game, but with a few new additions to your team. The action takes place in several regions all over the world (Philippines, Middle East, etc.) unlike the first game, where you were in Afghanistan the whole time. There are also a bunch of cutscenes following a few characters in their “off-duty” life in the United States (kind of boring). The general plot of the game though, is chasing down terrorists before they execute their complicated plans of blowing stuff up.

The game is very similar to the first MOH (as expected) and  it uses the Frostbite 2 game engine, which was featured in Battlefield 3. The graphics are VERY good and almost photo realistic at times. Unfortunately, this means that some computers may not be able to run the game at a decent frame rate. I found an issue where I would have horribly low frames per second at certain parts of the game, and it turned out that it was due to Origin downloading free map packs in the background (Zero Dark Thirty map pack was about 900 megabytes). When I stopped the downloads the game sped up. If you liked MOH1, you’ll like Warfighter.

reviewText:
Medal of Honor (2010) actually wasn't as bad as the reviews for it were. I remember the largest criticism being in the choice to be able to play as the Taliban in the multiplayer. I didn't play the multiplayer, so that hasn't hindered my review of this game.

In this reboot of the classic WWII series, the game is set in Afghanistan in very late 2001 and March 2002; being loosely based on Operation Anaconda, more specifically, the Battle of Shah-i-Kot and Battle of Takur Ghar. Takur Ghar is a mountain in the Shah-i-Kot Valley in Southeast Afghanistan where, at the time, Taliban and Chechan forces had dug themselves in with well over 500 forces encamped throughout the region.

The game's plot revolves around a number of soldiers from the Navy SEALs and various regiments from the US Army, such as the US Rangers and the Aviation Regiment. While a number of the characters don't actually meet, they help each other out at certain points during the game, like at one point, the Rangers are pinned down and the Aviation forces swing in to help them out. Then you take over as the Aviation team to sweep the area. The story is rather simple, sweep the area of enemy forces and, at times, the Navy SEALs are actually gathering intelligence, scouting forces ahead for the Army. Not an amazing story, but the amount of research the team put forward when it came to the accuracy of how many casualties were actually lost on the US side during the battles and the specific locations and tracking the troops movement from real life to fiction was neat. Basically, I applaud the effort with the research even if the story is dry.

Technical side, the games graphics are nice, but the AI on your side can get stuck at points and you might have to reload to a prior checkpoint, or worse, restart the whole level, that happened once. Some of the shadows bug out, but it wasn't that noticeable. Sound design is nice. Orchestra score is good, my only complaint that actually annoyed me was the soundtrack with like, Linkin Park. I hate Linkin Park. Seriously.

My only other serious complaint is that at some points of the game, apparently every muslim is an enemy and end up being killed by the US Army. Sure enough, in the game, everone you encounter is an enemy except from the first mission where you drive through a town and see some people, like the guy herding his goats across the street. It was a pretty big village and maybe I half expected to see a woman or child out in the streets, but there weren't any, so it became apparent that everyone you'd encountered at that point would become your enemy, which was very much the case. There wasn't any perspective as to who the civilians were or could be. And even the Northern Alliance, the Afghan army that the US had allied with, barely make an appearance. Instead, they're friendly fired upon by an angry guy in Langley. That was just like a WTF moment. I know some of that happened in real life, but it seemed a bit overkill here.

Still, a few minor complaints from an overall good FPS.

8.0/10

reviewText:
In Medal of Honor, brotherhood is an unspoken bond of trust and companionship through acts of honor where failing to leave a soldier behind isn’t an option and risking one’s life for the fate of another is common. The idea of brotherhood created Medal of Honor’s storyline, and it is the best storyline I have ever played in a tactical FPS thus far. Just like any FPS fan, I too become overly ecstatic about this genre: I can talk hours upon hours about it, give you my critical opinions down to exquisite detail, and discuss creative and strategic ways to deceive opponents online. And so, I wasn’t expecting much out of Medal of Honor considering how popular titles like Modern Warfare 2 have already set a nearly untouchable standard for the FPS genre, and I couldn’t foresee any title that was able to compete with that.

However, none have captured a story which is deep enough to really connect the player to the game’s storyline... until now. Although incredibly short, MoH’s campaign is done well and that’s an understatement. You play three different roles: Rabbit and Deuce, who are Tier 1 operatives, and Dante Adams, who is an Army Ranger. Usually, players are not able to become attached to the characters when the protagonist switches too many times and too quickly. But here, it works because it follows the concept of brotherhood mentioned above, covering what other popular shooters are missing in their campaign: a theme and the consistency of building a story around that theme.

Furthermore, you’re thrown into a variety of scenarios. Everything that you could possibly imagine that takes place in a war is in MoH’s single-player campaign, such as being ambushed by waves of enemies or being nearly obliterated by a hidden bomb. And what would you do if you jumped out of a helicopter and only had your knife as a weapon? It’s full of intense action through and through—enough that you don’t want to put the controller down.

Second, the game’s details are remarkable: Dust from the ground spits up from bullet fire, strobes continuously flash on your teammate’s shoulder when you switch to night-vision indicating who is a friendly, and even the sound of gunfire is different depending on where you are. Inside a wrecked plane, the bullets from a light machine gun has a tin-like sound with a subtle echo. Little details like these make you feel like you’re in a realistic battle.

Another feature that emphasizes realism is the communication between you and your AI teammates. Throughout the story, you’re directly spoken to and you’re given orders without any abrupt pop-up hints of where to go next. You’ll hear things like, “Rabbit, take the path at your six…” and “Go loud on Rabbit”, indicating what your next move should be. This is extremely effective since you learn to listen closely as well as learn how to be part of a team, making you much more involved in the combat.

Once you finish the campaign, Tier 1 mode is unlocked, where you aim to beat a level within a given time. That’s not all: There aren’t any checkpoints, so if you die, you start over; health regenerates slower; auto-aim assist and weapon’s crosshairs are disabled; and you cannot resupply on ammo from your allies. And need I emphasize the time limit? If you execute “skill kills”, like headshots and melee kills, then the clock temporarily stops. If the level is completed successfully, you earn a spot on the global leaderboards.

Despite how amazing the story is, there are several flaws in its gameplay. There are few texture problems where some buildings or environments take time to load while AI characters, who are standing in place, shift abruptly. As for the AI, my teammates at times ran into my line of fire - I promise I was not actually shooting them. And the enemy AI is not much of a concern as they are terribly predictable. In turn, they do become challenging to fight against on certain levels where they attack in groups or waves. My AI teammates despite being drawn to my line of fire are also very effective in killing the enemy without any of my help.

Medal of Honor’s minor weakness is its multiplayer. There are five different modes, three of which are objective-based: capturing and defending different points on the map. The other two consists of team deathmatch and hardcore. And let's not even go through the whole Taliban/Opposing Forces thing, or this review will never end. Just like single campaign, teamwork is crucial especially in objective games, like Objective Raid, where your goal is to defend two bases from the opposing team who has a goal to arm it and destroy it. In order to defend both bases, your team must spread out or the match could end in less than a minute.

The gameplay itself is entertaining especially considering that several playlists offer up to 24 players, but just like the game modes, the maps lack variety. There are eight in total and they feature valleys, mountains, and marketplaces, which more or less look the same to me, and they all feature a monochromatic scenery, making the maps rather bland. I couldn’t understand how the single campaign has such diverse terrain with colorful scenery while the maps in multiplayer do not.

Like I said in the beginning, I wasn’t expecting much out of Medal of Honor, but I was more than satisfied. While the multiplayer has its cons, it definitely has potential to be built into something more. The single-player campaign is enough to hold anyone through a gripping story with non-stop and fast-paced action and a trio of compelling characters. I should also mention that MoH is dedicated to America’s servicemen and I think it’s a job well done, no matter what the military bases say. Medal of Honor is one game you should be playing and one game that is now in competition with the rest.

reviewText: I got this game on a really good sale, I think it came through a Humble Bundle, and I was really excited to play it.  The Medal of Honor series is known for producing excellent first person shooters.\n\nI think this game was a big let down.  Maybe I was just too late to the party and expected a modern up to date shooter, but that's not what this is.  The AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The sound is just plain awful, insulting.  The gun mechanics are sloppy and unrealistic.  The visuals are flat and unconvincing.  This shooter isn't even worth $5.  That's particularly evident when games that have good single play and multi play components can be had for as little as $5 at times (get BF3 on sale, or even BF2).  Skip this title, it missed the mark.

reviewText: Medal of Honor is a reboot of the classic WWII franchise and is set within the modern day conflict in the middle east. The story campaign tries to focus on the epic yet somewhat cliche'd story of a group of special forces soldiers doing super secret missions and the like, we've heard that all before. But what makes Medal of Honor different from other games in the genre is it tries to maintain a realistic, gritty war atmosphere with its authentic and fantastic sounds, real-world weapons and most controversially the taliban. While some may pass on the single player due to its been there done that" feeling thanks to call of duty
recommended: and is recommended for anyone looking for a good time. But where the game really shines is in its multiplayer
hoursPlayed: taking the authentic sound and feel of the game into the online battlefield. The modes feature capture point
voteText: attack and defend
helpfulPercent: and elimination among a few others. The graphics and sound are great and while multiplayer is fun to play
votesHelpful: it does suffer a bit from little customization of weapons and characters
votesTotal: set classes
votesFunny:
and frustrating hitbox detection. Even so the game does manage to be fun and is something different if you're looking for something other than call of duty or battlefield. Just stay away from its sequel.

> PROS
Great graphics and phenominal sound
Decent single player campaign
Variety of online modes
Authentic feel

> CONS
Bullet sponge enemies and annoying hitboxes
Few maps to choose from
Small amount of online players
Hackers online can ruin matches
Cliche'd story

BOTTOM LINE: Pretty Good
Medal of Honor is what you'd get if you merged Battlefield and Call of Duty together
commentsCount: and its pretty good. The multiplayer is a refreshing and authentic alternative to call of duty but not quite big enough to be its big brother battlefield.\nRecommended 8/10\n"

reviewText:
I went into Medal of Honor expecting another gritty, brown, cover-shooting FPS, clicking away until the brown terrorist hiding behind brown rocks stop moving. What you get is, well, that but not nearly as deary and grinding as I had anticipated and even did some things pretty well. Maybe it's because it's been a few years since I've played a single player modern military shooter.

First off, the campaign is head scratchingly short. For a series that has always focused on single player it's a little puzzling that so much time and money was put into a 3-5 hour campaign. That being said, short is better than long and grindy. There is a good mix of stealth based and all out war game play, with vehicle and sniper sections scattered through out that keep things fresh. You jump between three view points that tie together nicely whcih prevents the transitions from being jarring. One of the things that I thought they did well was conveying the uncertainty of who is a target and who is a civilian, or even a friendly. I do think they missed an opportunity to put those decisions on the player, as most of those situations occur in either scripted sections or cut scenes, but still, it didn't go unnoticed.

There were a few more details that helped lift this game a bit above mediocre. The guns felt varied and solid, although the shotgun is overpowered, and headshots look and sound satisfying. My favorite detail was the sound design. There's this really cool thing when you're standing near a squad member who's speaking and you can hear their voice both through the radio and normally. It doesn't actually effect anything but it's a nice detail that's realistic and helps with immersion and makes me wonder why I haven't heard it in more games.

There's no reason to run out and buy this at full price but if modern FPSs are your thing or you get the chance at a good price it's worth a quick play through. A note on the value: I didn't play more than just loading into a couple of games but the multiplayer is still up and running and there were players. You may need to go into the settings file and force the DirectX to version 9. There's also what they call Tier 1 mode which is just leader boards for completing the campaign levels while hitting or beating various statistical goals (time, accuracy, melee kills, etc).

reviewText:
A ridiculously railroaded, bland, unpolished corridor shooter.
The AI is non existent. Enemies just run to their designated spot and shoot in your general direction. Your teammates always run into your gunfire and grenades. The gameplay is insipid with plenty of point and click games and turret sections. You constantly have to wait for your teammates to open doors for you, which probably elongates this short game by another 2 hours. The weapons don't feel powerful and shooting them is just unsatisfactory.
Story wise... you shoot brown people, while military guys scream at each other. And then you save 2 guys. That's the extent of it that I understood.
This game is just depressing, and not in a good way.
4/10

Cons:

reviewText: I'm having some fun playing this but other times I just want to get to the end. The characters are boring. Seems like everybody is a hardened white commando from about the same background and with the same attitude and feelings about everything except for one black commander who might as well be white and one white general or CIA guy or something who should be a lot better actor. The sound is bad. There's lots of err... homoerotic commando whispering in your ear as you stealthily follow the one and only path to penetrate" your next objective like Dorothy for instance. I like it but the whispering voice sounds the same way no matter if that commando is in front of you
date:
behind you or fifty feet in front of you. And your name keeps changing as you switch identities for no apparant reason. The cities aren't much bigger than farms. The guy directing you often tells me to do things but I have trouble following his instructions. It helps to press H so that your objective lights up for a little while. Its not really that important because there aren't any different ways to go but it took me some time to figure that out.

Quite a few times I've been unable to progress and been forced to restart a mission. I'm often annoyed with the game choosing my weapon. Can't I be allowed to make any decisions? I've played other games that allow me to pick weapons  and choose paths and my name. That's how I prefer it. This game doesn't allow a lot of freedom in allowing you to pick what you'll do next or how you'll do it and its very repetitious. There's one mission where you are taking cover in some crumbling mud shack and the enemy streams in forever down the hills around you. It just gets tiring picking them off. Hard to believe they would waste that many guys on that pathetic tactic but I suppose it could happen.

What's going on with that Barret sniper rifle view? Its like they mounted a camera on the back of a camel walking on rocky terrain in high winds.

The graphics are good and there's a lot of action. Its not as good as taking a walk but its better than raking leaves. This game is not sleep inducing. It'll tire you out but it will also make you feel restless and and angry. If you need to fall asleep I recomend Eurotruck simulator."

reviewText:
Everything about this game is just wrong. I cant even tell if I will manage to finish the game cause it is so boring. I play it on the hardest difficulty and yet everyone (including your mates) is totally dumb. Your enemies will hide behind every corner and let their heads away from the cover so you can shot them.

The game is so boring cause of the repetitiveness, you just walk into the room and shoot about 4 enemies there, then you wait for your team mates to come and regroup around the door and sometimes they let you kick the door which is the best feature in the game. Team mates are just a pain in the ♥♥♥ cause they wont shot anybody yet they talk trash all the time.

Also it feels so sterile while you dont have anything to decide about. Everything is straight lined and you just have to follow the rules, there is no other way. You simply go through 3 meters wide corridor, shoot 5 enemies, wait for your team mate to do something and then repeat.

If your read this, please stay away from this game. It's ♥♥♥♥in trash. Hate it

reviewText:
This is a promising game at first. Great looks, great playability, different game mechanics... But it is just another CoD. I actually bought it because I thought i was NOT going to be like that, not another massive, commercial, non-gamer oriented, boring, empty and soulless FPS.

The campaign is really boring and repetitive, too lineal, very unoriginal and really, really short and easy even on the hardest setting. I finished it with just 5 hours of playtime (and I repeated the first missions a few times due to some hardware problems). So, if you're looking for a nice singleplayer experience, this is not what you're looking for.

If MP is your thing, then... dont buy it either. Its nothing special. If you like AAA military FPS, get any CoD or Battlefield. Basically the same thing but with many more players online, although here you might find less 13-year-olds screaming at their mics or hackers. Benefits of being less massive.

reviewText: I couldn't even get past the first hour without wanting to vomit from all of the military porn forced into the game and down my throat.  If games like CoD make your willy hard and need to get off on some American soldier power fantasy, maybe this will give you your fix.  If you have self respect steer clear (and go play Spec Op: The Line for an honest look into the mind of a modern soldier).  Luckily I got this from a Humble Bundle so I didn't pay much and my money went to worthy charities; still I think the devs should pay me for the hour I slogged through in the game (and the shooting wasn't even that fun).

reviewText:
MEDAL OF HONOUR
A po-faced version of Call of Duty without any of the overblown action scenes

Rating 4/10

A competent but incredibly dull trek around Afghanistan. It takes itself far too seriously for what it essentially a heavily scripted action game. You could say it's like the game version of the film Act of Valour.

It's not all bad and there a couple of good set pieces which are effectively a last stand scenario reminiscent of the best Call of Duty set pieces however more often than not it's a repetitive slog through dull mountain ranges shooting at brain dead wack a mole enemies. There is nothing particularly new and fresh about Medal of Honour just a feeling of déjà vu, you've played this game 10 times before, it's just had different names.

It's also incredibly short, clocking in at around 3 hours for the single player campaign and that's taking your time on the hardest difficulty. Just when you think the game is about to start it ends, it feels rushed much like the disappointing ending to Kane and Lynch Dog Days.

Little did they know that Tariq was actually a sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who had lured them into a trap. After the Americans prove that ♥♥♥♥♥ wrong and kill all of his buddies, the Americans interrogate Tariq to find out that there are over 9000 talibanz waiting up in the ♥♥♥♥-i-kot valley to shoot them. After this part, every other mission is just securing stuff, blowing stuff up, driving around, blowing more stuff up, shooting people, being shot at, actually suffering a bullet wound, some on rail levels, and dying. reviewText: This game takes everything that was bad about Call of Duty and manages to make it worse. The campaign is mindless, funneling you from one menial task to the next with no agency or challenge. The multiplayer is worse than most f2p games and less populated to boot, sporting the noisy, cluttered visuals and random one-hit spawn kills from across the map characteristic of the worst in the genre. There are no other features. You have to endure 3.5 minutes of an unskippable cutscene before you're even allowed to play the campaign, and in certain scripted events you don't even need to shoot anybody to stay alive. It's also four hours long. That is not hyperbole.

reviewText: This is the first time I've actually managed to play all the way through one of these big-budget modern warfare shooters, and now I understand what people mean when they call them big dumb spectacles. This is a game that never let me make my own decisions, held my hand the entire way through, and never gave me any context or reason for killing hundreds of men with overwhelming force - but it was still fun, with plenty of intense action and good variety in gameplay, and obviously well put together. Consider grabbing it if it's on sale, but there's no way I'd pay full price for a game style I just don't like.\n\nFull review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/10/medal-of-honor.html

reviewText: A solid shooter, and the multiplayer is fun and well made. But the game feels like a teaser for Battlefield 3, the single player is embarrassingly short, and the multiplayer has a laughably small upgrade system (There are 2 team specific guns per class and then an extra one you can unlock). It looks like Battlefield, plays like a cross of BF3 and COD, and then comes up short in content. It's like paying to play a demo. Get it cheap? Worth the couple hours of playtime you will get. Otherwise, avoid.

reviewText:
Good ambientation ruined by some technical issues.

I got this game from the Origin Humble Bundle. Even though the bundle was completely worth buying it, installing this game wasn't. I have only played the single player game which runs on a different engine than the multiplayer's but I won't bother with it.

Story wise, it is a short campaign (4-5h at max) with no replayability because everything is so lineal that apart from beautiful enviroments it doesn't have enough motivation to even finish it.

The single player uses a console-like FOV and there is no way to change it. It feels zoomed (like if you play the whole game looking through a scope) and therefore it's very uncomfortable to play for more than 20min.

Another negative point is mouse sensitivity. By default, MOH has mouse acceleration set to true which you can change but there is also some weird thing about sensitivity. Even on the lowest setting your aim moves faster than most people would desire. You can lower your dpi to solve this if you have a margin for that, obviously.

Overall you're better off watching a movie like Black Hawk Down or Lone Survivor if you want some action.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
No point in getting MoH now.

I recived it as a gift (whom I forgot to thank) when it was $60. Would it be worth buying, not really.

You can think of the game as COD skinned with battlefield assests. The game is currently lost as the war(s) in the middle east are done for the most part.

While it's designed to make you feel like a special ops team member, it's just... not that tactical. A lot of running and gunning.

Multiplayer was a terrible experience, but the single player story had some content in it.

The joke is, single player was done in one engine, and then multiplayer in another. This was at the point in time when EA was working on the Frostbite engine.

4/10

reviewText:
Hi, everybody!

OK, So I have just come out of a 30h stint of Dishonoured, so I'm going to make a couple of comparisons to that here.

OK So the good/normal stuff.

It's a Rail Shooter = There is only one way to progress one possible direction of events can unfold. This is good in that it directs the story in the direction that the writers want it to go. I like rail shooters, Half Life is a rail shooter, by definition.

The Shooting controls.
YAY SOMEONE GOT IT RIGHT! The way it is set up, by default, is how I, and other pro FPS players, have our controls (mostly).
Crouch and sprint whilst the button is depressed, not on toggle. Rifle Zoom on Rcklick, also on toggle. WOOT WOOT! Really this is only a little thing as it can usually be changed in the keyboard settings, but I didn't have to change it, for once. Would have been nice if melee was mapped to F, tho. (usually I would have it on E, but that was needed for peeking, which didn't feel as good as the Dishonoured's version)

The Stealth/Knifing - there were about 6 opportunites to employ this, if you wanted to. Which is reasonable for a gun-focussed campaign. The stealth itself was only OK... you had to kill in the prescribed order, if you went off the script, everyone is alerted and it devolves into a gun fight. I also feel that the enemies hit harder during the stealth sections if you stuffed it up and started a gun fight, as an incentive to do it the way the writers wanted you to. You could run behind someone and they would not hear you. But stealth the wrong guy (or the right guy in the wrong order) and he'd alert the whole base.

Health bar - was a fast-regenerating red mist that surrounds the vision, similar to CoD, I believe, but better in that it only took a couple of hits (3?) before I was restarting at the checkpoint. Good and bad.The mechanic suited the game andt he fast-paced storyline.


Enemies - these would flank and attack, and dive for cover, the AI seemed fine, their accuracy was acceptable. Exept the snipers.

Sniping (Barret sections)
These were pretty good. You had wind, bullet travel time, and an IR camera to deal with.everything was there except the recoil. Oh there is one bit where you are sniping and your spotter is calling shots. He does a fairly hopeless job of it. and their snipers are useless shots. Then they had Dragonov's VS our Barret.

Run-And-Gun (the story proper)
Mostly fine, sections of running to find cover, picking your shots, and not getting shot or grenaded in the process. You can always ask your allies for more ammo if you're out, too - which is kinda nice. There are some points (you will realise them when it happens) where eventually you realise the enemies have infinite respawn, and the nex event is actually triggered by you moving up closer to the enemy stronghold.  I didn't really like that mechanic. Nor did I like the absolute reliance on Air support to take out dug-in targets such as AA turrets and mortar fire. What would the Rangers do without the Airfoce, I wonder? Hmmm... drop a grenage instead of a signal flare, I imagine.

Story Telling:
I didn't like how you were constantly being told parts of the story through different Character's eyes. At least, I didn't like how it was done in this game. Usually when this is done, it creates some extra layer of depth to the game, due to the new character having a different mechanic, such as Raven in MSG2  Where you swithced from gun play to sword play. In this, when you change guys, you swap your M4 for (I dunno, some other full auto assault rifle. I plead ignorance). There wasn't really enough difference in each character to truely make each one feel unique. It really was just more of the same as the other guy buy now they are calling me something different when they talk to me.

The story: (no spoilers)
Was a nod to the boys on the ground, their trials, and their hardships. This was done in the outworking of the story, quite well. not really a spoiler, but if you don't want any clues about the game story at all... Bullets or bones? Bones heal... Jump!" would be my favourite line in the movie/game. Their desperation felt sincere
date: That's a rare thing in gaming story lines. I feel like it was a pity the game was only 5h long
recommended: but it told the story they wanted it to
hoursPlayed: without drawing it out - which maight actually leave you feeling cheated if it went on 'forever' and that ending was the one that you got. it was a good length for the story that was told. Just the game itself was well done and felt a bit short

reviewText:
This review is for the game ''Medal of Honor'',a first-person military shooter video game,developed by the video game company Danger Close Games(Single-player) and EA Digital Illusions CE(multiplayer).It was published by Electronic Arts and released in October 12,2010 for NA and October 15,2010 for Europe.The game uses the Unreal Engine 3 for the single player campaign and the Frostbit 1.5 for the multiplayer mod.The game is available for Microsoft Windows,Playstation 3 and Xbox 360.

Single player-campaign plot

The campaign,of the thirteenth installment of the Medal of Honor series,takes place during the first days of the invasion of Afghanistan,in 2002.The story might be based on on the events that took place during Operation Anaconda that occured in March 2002,approximately six months after 9/11.In the game you will get to experience warfare that happened in reality like the seizing of Bagram Airfield,the Battle of Takur Ghar and the Battle of Shah-i-Kot.

Throughout the game you will be exchanging roles between the Navy SEAL DEVGRU ''Rabbit'',a Delta Force sniper code-named ''Deuce'',Ranger Dante Adams and the Apache helicopter gunner Brad Hawkins.Apart they will face great battles and will have to overcome great obstacles in order to protect their country,their freedom and their well-being.

Multiplayer
Multiplayer is really rich in weapon customization,perk unlockables,achievements,statistics and ribbons giving the sense of fulfillment to the player while playing multiplayer.Sadly the multiplayer is quite dead already.Unfortunately no more that 100-200 gamers play daily.

Recap
Medal of Honor series used to be Electronic Arts' flagship.Unfortunately interest got lost since EA focused more on the development was focused on creating and expanding the Dragon Age series,the Dead Space series,the Crysis series and especially the Battlefield series,whom today are EA's flagship.

Pros
+Beautiful graphics
+Interesting fast paced storyline,sometimes heartbreaking
+Exciting and easy to use shooting mechanisms

Cons
-Deceased multiplayer
-Linear mission based storyline(too linear for my taste)

Q:Do i recommend this game?
A:Depends.If you want to explore the single player campaign and progress through the Medal of Honor universe absolutely yes.If you buy it for the Multiplayer mod do not bother you'll be playing alone or with a bunch of 12 year olds.

P.S I didn't refer much on the Plot section because i didn't want to spoil the game to you.Buy it and play it thoroughly.
Support the developers.Electronic Arts thank you for this game.

reviewText: I felt the single-player campaign was reasonably well-done, and deserved better reviews.  My complaints would be that it was pretty short (I finished it in about 4 hours) and some of the missions suffered from the CoD syndrome of endless waves of enemies.  But overall it felt more realistic than most of its contemporaries, and the nod to real-life battles (Operation Redwings, later made famous by the movie Lone Survivor), was fun imo.

reviewText: while there was only a few bugs, the new Medal of Honor game was horrible. I found that in several parts of the game you didnt even need to shoot the game would just “choo choo” tug along in the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cliche’d story. And at no point did the game make me adapt or did it change in any way i literally just sat behind cover headshotting any dumbass who popped out of cover with my LITERALLY INFINITE AMMO. and when i wasnt doing that is was using or on some incredibly powerful weapon laying waste to anything that had so much as a pulse and wasnt white. It was kind of unsettling it all felt like some creepy power trip some criminally insane person would have before committing a mass murder. AND THERE WAS LITERALLY LIKE 8? WEAPONS IN THE STORY MODE?? AND YOUR STARTING GEAR WAS PRETTY MUCH ALL THE SAME WEAPON? AN AUTOMATIC WITH AN ACOG. oh maybe your offhand is a shotgun or something at time but the ♥♥♥♥in M4 or whatever that tacticool SEAL guy was using were pretty much the same gun. AND THE STORY IS LIKE EXACLTY LIKE MW2 (SPOILER) MAIN CHARACTER DIES AS YOU PLAY AS STATIC MAIN CHARACTER 2. i was shocked as i finished the game, DUMBFOUNDED as the credits began to roll. IT ROMANTICIZED WAR AND THE MILITARY LIFE SO MUCH. SURE ITS NOT A BAD THING BUT WAR IS ♥♥♥♥ING WAR OK THERES NOTHING PRETTY ABOUT IT. i honestly think this game is ♥♥♥♥ing dangerous. not like how the ♥♥♥♥ing media paints GTAIV to teach kids to kill but this game says WAR IS FUN, YOULL MAKE GOOD FRIENDS, AND EVERYONE WILL RESPECT YOU, KILL BROWN PEOPLE. This game felt like a ♥♥♥♥ing social experiment and i paid way too much for it (Humble Bundle $1)

reviewText:
Single Player:
Game starts off really strong with you thrown into the middle of a conflict following your squad through a war ravaged middle eastern town. The more you work with them though the more it's apparent that they will constantly hold back, waiting for you - the only badass who can storm a freaking target and use cover effectively to avoid fire - to clear the way before they move up.

Would be awesome if the game relied less on the constant leap-frogging dynamic of move up" .. "wait" .. "move up" .. "wait" .. but if you can get past this
date: it's a pretty well done linear shooter.\n\nThe only catch is - it's the same old formula that's done a million times in other games and a million times better."

reviewText:
In the summer of 2011, I made the horrific mistake of buying this game just for early access to the Battlefield 3 beta (also, BF3 turned out to be a disappointment that drove me back to BC2).

The single player campaign is basically a crappier Call of Duty. Call of Duty may be rehashed garbage but at least its campaigns are entertaining enough to keep me engaged to the end. I could not say the same with the first hour or so of this awful game. Also, why the heck does this not use Frostbite for single player? That would have kept me interested a little longer. Btw, I heard that the campaign was even worse in the Warfighter sequel that proved embarrassing for EA.

The multiplayer mode uses a limited-destruction version of Frostbite (WTF, DICE?). It's a horrible console port with boring maps, few vehicles, and no mod tools for the community to make their own maps (as is the trend these days, sadly).

On the technical side, the graphics are nothing to be impressed about. Optimization is passable, but won't make up for the very unimpressive gameplay.

Please do not buy this game. If you want a brainless single player shooter from a greedy publisher, then play Modern Warfare 2 or 3. If you want an atrocious multiplayer experience, go download the blandest, worst-rated user-created maps from Counter-Strike community websites.

P.S. A message for EA:
