reviewText:
Note: This is only the single player, didn't play the multiplayer. The mechanics are servicable. The graphics are generic. What little you can glean from the characters are that they are murderous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. The story is a Tea Partier's wankfest.  I guess that's normal for this type of game.

There is one interesting setpiece; it's a fighter jet graveyard.  You're only there for a few minutes though, and there are fighter jet graveyards in most modern military shooters anyway.

There is exactly one part of the game that's fun: Your orders are to kill everyone with a heavy machine gun in a seemingly abandoned village. You get to a hut, break in, and then play Defend The Hut for ten minutes.  It was fun because over the course of the mission, RPGs kept taking out the walls until there was almost no cover and I had only 14 bullets left at the end.

Finished the campaign in two nights, probably could have done it in one if I had started an hour earlier.

If you're looking for a military shooter, how about Spec Ops: The Line instead?  That one is waaaaaaaaay more interesting in ABSOLUTELY EVERY SINGLE RESPECT.

reviewText:
Since the MoH-series is sort of a big brand, I was expecting a somewhat decent shooter and started out playing it with an open mind. The game is 3 years old when I got it via the Humble Bundle. I was SOOO wrong. In fact I will rate this game as the perfect example of how a company can screw up when they release a single player game on steam.

It starts out even before you get to play.
First you need to sign in to an EA-account to play... and then you need to enter the serial code for the game.
Entering the serial is a pain in the unmentionable because the game only lets you type, no cut'n'paste from the clipboard. AND to view the code you need to ALT-TAB between the game and Steam.

So what do you get for doing this? Nothing. It's not like the game saves your progress online or anything. The only reason for doing this is that EA now ties the game to your EA account as a form of DRM. This means that you can't sell the game to someone else.

Sell it? Wait? That was already impossible in the first place, since this is a Steam, right?
Yes, all the pain you just went through to find your EA account details, enter the key was for nothing.

It does not end here though.

In case you want to reformat your pc or delete the game, you must remember to deauthorize the game. If you don't you'll some day end up having spent all your installations" and the game will simply sit in your Steam library as a game you can install
date:
but never get to play.
This is again EA's stupid extra DRM. They should have removed this for the Steam version but probably didn't bother because it would cost them a few hours of programmer wages.


Then finally you get to the game.
I remember back in 2010 when I didn't buy the game. There was something fishy about it. The SP was being developed by another team on another platform... Surely this was being done because "every game needs a single player campaign" and the result clearly shows. You don't need to play for more than a few minutes to realize that this game was made to make a quick buck
recommended:
not to become the best game ever... or anything.


The first impression is... hmmm...were graphics that bad back in 2010?
Overall things look fine
voteText: flat looking tekstures mashed in between fine bumpmapped textured... and every single hut in the game looks exactly the same. If it wasn't for the high detail in textures this game could belong in 2003.\n\nLevel design is extremely bad

I have difficulty in comparing this to any other game or time. MoH is simply the prime example of a shooter on rails. I have never seen a game with such a little possibility of choice.(And I've played FPS's since they showed up the mid 90'es. )

However, it's Medal of Honor:

It has absolutely nothing new to add to the bland, tired genre of games it belongs to, besides the emotional story the blandness hides behind.

Cool. It's story is a little deep, and a little Go America"-y

reviewText:
Single-player: The whole game was ok. The modern setting I liked, the graphics were also pretty good. What I didn't like were some of the bugs. It's been a while since I played it, but the only thing I CAN remember (yes, short memory... I already forgot what I just typed) were the NPC's that stopped doing anything mid-game which resulted in replaying the entire level all over again. The story was ok, nothing special. It lacked a lot of suspense and action (which is, of course, realistic, but I'm not playing games for 100% realism). Nothing noteworthy.

Multiplayer: Not bad, but the fact that there is (was ?) so much spawnkilling killed this game very quickly for me. Is it that hard to create a solid spawn system (Modern Warfare 2 could do it) ?

If you don't like MW this might be for you. Otherwise, stick with MW (more action, faster gameplay, better controls, more polished and EXCELLENT multiplayer).

[Rating: 66/100]

reviewText:
This is a well done FPS that somehow went under the radar during a time when the Call of Duty and Battlefield franchises began  saturating the market. The single player campaign is short, but it takes players through a series of fun and exciting missions, based on real world events during the 2001 invasion of Afghanistan, specifically Operation Anaconda.

I was impressed with the authenticity that went into the game. Alot of the terminology is something that military folks might only understand. The weapons were done well, and there is a good assortment of hardware for players to get their hands on.

Overall, I think Danger Close did a great job with the SP portion but I wish they would've also done the MP portion. DICE (Battlefield), for some reason, was contracted to develop the MP portion. In my opinion, the MP is just stale and too much like Battlefield. Many of the features that are available in SP are not available in MP.

Weapons and damage model in MP are also horrible. Hit detection, is most notably, the worst I've seen in any game. Would not recommend MP.

reviewText: 6.5/10 TJBs
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Medal of Honor (2010) not to be confused with Medal of Honor (1999) on the PlayStation. Medal of Honor was released on 2010 by EA (Electronic Arts). Medal of Honor takes place in Afghanistan, and was actually developed under the inspiration of American Special Forces.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: The Medal of Honor storyline will have you bouncing back and forth between four different characters, all the while trying to keep up with the unfolding conflict between the USA and with a group similar to the Taliban.
The game starts with you playing as a character from a Navy SEAL named “Rabbit”. You will also play once as an Apache gunner, then you alternate between a Delta Force Sniper and and Army Ranger, and finally ending the game from Rabbits perspective.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=525418863

Let me say, this story is just a mess. Within the first twenty minutes of the game, you start switching between characters. There are games that can successfully switch playable characters and you comprehend the story being told, but none of the characters are memorable to drive this method. Honestly, the only two teams I remember participating on were the Navy SEAL's and the Delta Force Sniper group. Everyone else is a blur of “and then we did that”.

While the story was interesting, and at times upsetting, (as it can be, when an outsider in a comfortable desk is giving orders which make no sense to the boots on the ground...) the story narrative is hard to follow because of all the character switching, making the story completely tangled and forgettable. Which is sad, as it could have been fantastic.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=525418883

Gameplay: The controls are pretty basic as far as most FPS's go. You can alternate between a Primary weapon, a secondary, and a pistol. You also have a melee attack for close fighting, and grenades.
Depending on whom you're playing as, you have different weapons. For example the seals used a M16-modded rifle, and secondary was a sniper. While in contrast the Delta Sniper group all had silencer modifications on pistols and snipers.
While fighting you can swap out, or pick up weapons... ...but again, that's a footnote and just an expected feature in FPS's.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=525418900

Achievements: There are no Steam Achievements within Medal of Honor. However, in multiplayer there are “Awards” and unlockables as you level up and obtain “skill”.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528129615

Price: Medal of Honor is priced at $19.99, I came by my copy from a Humble bundle years ago. The story mode (or “Campaign”) will last about 4 hours, probably less depending on the difficulty you play at and how hard you push forward.
There is mutliplayer, but I'll add a section to my review to discuss multiplayer features more in depth. Unless you play multiplayer, $19.99 is far too high a price.

Multiplayer: I logged on several times to see how the community was doing, and naturally there are a few people still playing the game. But there was only one game going actively, the rest were empty.
The Multiplayer is what you would expect: you run around, help capture objectives, fill enemies with bullets, get murdered by the guy who's played nonstop since release... 'ya know, the “norms”.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528129217

As you complete multiplayer games, you get experience errr excuse me “skill” points (which acts the same way as experience points in other games), you rank up the classes you've been playing, which unlocks bonuses for that class.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528129359

History: I can't complete this review without saying that I admire the Medal of Honor series. The first game I played was the original Medal of Honor released by DreamWorks Interactive in 1999 for the PlayStation.
Looking back, the story from the 1999 version wasn't so great or interesting. However, it's easier to forgive because of the limitations on hardware at that time. It's a bit more difficult to forgive when a game was released in 2010.
While I do admire the series, it is always been 100% biased for the United States Agenda. (at times I feel falls close to “propaganda”) At least the Medal of Honor series treats the soldiers respectfully and honorably. In the end I care about the soldiers, not the power hungry politicians and governments fueling the wars and death.

Conclusion: Medal of Honor was a disappointment, and I really hate to say that. The story was short, it has emphasis on online content and leaderboards, the story was terribly presented, the gameplay was mediocre at best. From a big name like “Medal of Honor”, there's a fairly long and impressive heritage, making this game's failures all that much more disappointing.
Did the game work? Yeah. Is there still some Multiplayer? Yeah. Can you play and shoot up people? Yeah. What sets this game apart? Nothing. You can take it or leave it. For 20 dollars get a game that actually has a story. If you want online competitive play, go grab a game like Call of Duty, Counter Strike, Team Fortress, there are many choices of FPS which still has a community.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527199532

------Edits and updates------
Edit/Update October 03, 2015:
A very hardy thankyou to Angfucious for spell checking and grammar correcting this piece before I posted it. I wanted to make sure I was as articulate and spot on as possible.

reviewText:
Medal of Honor is a bland, shallow and uninspired first person shooter very clearly developed and marketed to cash in on the success that the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare series was seeing at the time, and in that regard it falls flat on its face.

Lets start with the positives. The graphics are pretty good for 2010 and the scene when you're fighting your way up a mountain while an AC-130 gunship fires on targets in the valley below was pretty cool.

Now that that's out of the way.

MoH is a short, boring corridor shooter occasionally broken up by boring turret sections. Your whole squad are walking ammo boxes that you can request ammo from whenever you get low, so ammo conservation and battlefield scavenging do not exist. The shooting is bland and the guns feel weak. There is hardly any weapon variety and almost no enemy variety.

Friendly and enemy AI is generally bad. Enemies stand in the middle of open ground during firefights facing the wrong direction. Almost every time I saw a friendly AI throw a grenade it hit whatever he was using as cover, even during a scripted sequence when one of your squad members uses a grenade to clear a cave entrance. This got me killed more than once. Friendlies will CONSTANTLY run into your fire, blocking enemies and complaining about friendly fire, although as far as I could tell, you can't actually harm them.

On multiple occasions scripted sequences would break and require me to load the previous checkpoint. The checkpoints were badly placed and dying would often result in having to replay long portions of the mission and watch unskippable scripted sequences all over again.

All of the characters are the same generic, bearded tier 1 operator that contemporary shooters are known for. By the end of the game I didn't know anything about any of the characters or their personalities, which wouldn't be so bad if the game weren't constantly trying to make you feel comradery with your squad and to empathise with their struggle.

There are a very limited number of graphics options and the FOV is so low that I had to sit a few metres away from my screen in order to not feel nauseous.

reviewText:
Cons:

- It's a boring, so scripted that if you by accident leave one enemy alive (and that is possible since AI is dumb as s**t) sitting behind some cover, game won't even load next part of the level and you can fall through the floor!

- You can't open the door until the game lets you do it.

- You can't sit on a buggy until game tells you to do so.

- Pistol has an infinite amount of ammo, it's accurate as a sniper rifle and reloads in 1 sec. Reality FTW!

- Dialogue is tedious.

- Game tries to copy over the top action from CoD but it fails miserably.

- You need to manually enter CD due to copy protection. As if someone would want to pirate this PoS!

- Looks ugly. Feels ugly. Plays ugly. Your character is ugly. Enemies are ugly.

- And once more, is boring. Won't even finish it, it's not worth the time!

Pros

- Runs nice on pretty much anything. Coz it's ugly.

- Hmmmm... thinking, thinking...


All in all, avoid like a plague. It's not the worst game out there, for sure, but this was supposed to be AAA title, and as such is a failure. It's not original, it's not funny, it will only take few bucks from you and will give nothing in return!

Avoid!

reviewText:
This game had great potential, it could've been fun but they made event registry happen client sided. This results in people with high latency killing you after you're done killing them, sometimes a few seconds later, when they're dead. As a result it feels very unrewarding to be good or not at FPS games when any brazilian who can't aim to save his life manages to kill you 3 seconds after you've taken cover, because of client-sided event registry.

Same thing happens in all Battlefield titles, and it needs to stop. The foreign hordes of are ruining our gameplay with their high pings, make them play on servers on their own bloody continent.

That, and the only way they ever get kills is by spamming noob tubes or rockets anyway.

Now if you'll excuse me, i'll go back to playing a game without either ♥♥♥♥♥♥ balance or a netcode enforced skill cap.

reviewText:
Medal of Honor is, without any exaggeration, the most bland game I have ever seen in my entire life. It is repetitive, there is no story, gameplay is extremely basic and no feeling of progression as you go through the extremely short (5 hours in my case) game.

The game is set entirely in Afghan tundra, with the exception of one urban level and another one set in an airbase and although  tundra is not a common environment in videogames, it is extremely overused here. Gameplay consists of simple first-person shooter action broken up by vechile sections. There was nothing in that respect that I haven't seen before.

The story was so extremely uninteresting that I forgot it in it's entirety inbetween playing it and writing this review and although that was some time, I can say with certainity that there was no thing going on for the entire duration of the game. I was simply doing stuff without any form of greater context, so my memory of it all is now a miasma of brown deserts with equally brown-uniformed men trodding around while firing the same boring guns at other brown men. The only thing I remembered was one nice moment where you were given the impression that you would be overwhelmed by the enemy in a lengthy standoff, but the opportunity for the game to do something interesting is wasted when you are saved by a helicopter at the last moment. But without doubt the worst moment in the entire story aspect is when I didn't realise the game was over untill the end credits appeared. I seriously was just playing a mission as difficult or interesting as all the other ones untill all of a sudden a cutscene came up where I found some guy dead who I had to rescue since the moment the game had reached 50% of it's runtime. Then the game just stopped. In other words, a story thread that only spanned part of the game was resolved and for some reason the game took the moment to run off in it's entirety. Nothing I did in the first half of the game changed anything meaningful about the rest of the game.

Then I tried the multiplayer. Although I have to admit that my brief experience was satisfying, that was mostly because of that I found that I was better at it than most playing. That is not a weird thing, considering that all you do in the multiplayer is run around and shoot eachother in microscopic environments. Therefore noone who plays first person shooters regularly is still playing that, which explains my experience. After 20 minutes I was done, I quit and never returned.

If you ask me, this game is just boring. I would not recommend that you pay money for it at all to play it.

reviewText:
Single Player Review: Is this game good? That depends on what you are looking for and how you define it. Its about Afghanistan and thats a touchy subject.

I don't think that Danger Close was trying to make light of the war in Afghanistan. I also think a distinction needs to be made between a war game/movie, and an action game/movie. War movies should not be fun, they should be dramatic, even painful, as a way to pay respect to the gravity of the situation/people invoved. Whereas action movies/games can be fun, because they generally focus around a caricatured protagonist who is the embodiment of some particular virtue.

This distinction would be what separates Spec Ops: The Line from Call of Duty Modern Warfare 1-3.

If this game is a war game then yes. If this game is an action game then no. But that distinction can really only be made in the mind of the player.

reviewText:
I think this was a great game, but there were a few problems with it.

Pros:
Good storyline
Interactive gameplay
Hitboxes aren't messed up
20+ weapons at your disposal

Cons:
Graphics aren't amazing, but they're good
Very short campaign (took me about 3.5 hours to finish it)
A few glitched areas
No graphics changing settings (I looked, but I didn't find any)

This game doesn't require an amazing computer to run (My 500 dollar computer runs it fine). Overall, it's a good game for the price. I got it on Humble Bundle, but it's easily worth 20 dollars. No more though. ( assuming it comes with multiplayer)
The multiplayer is the same as COD or CSGO; filled with hackers and (wanna-be) trolls. It's fine, but I much prefer the campaign mode. If you're looking for a casual shooter to spend some time on, you should get this. But if you expect an abnormal amount from your games, prob not. 3.8/5 Would reccomend to anyone who enjoys casual shooters.

reviewText:
I never really thought that Medal of Honor would ever get my attention. I always thought it was just another top-notch military shooter with a stupid villain and a world consuming problem (COD, Battlefield 3). It's a military shooter yea, but the game doesn't serve you a stupid story with completely forgettablte characters. In Medal of Honor you embark on intense missions against the Talibans over the course of 3 days. You play as several characters instead of only one. Missions after missions the pace is kept to a comfortable level ranging from stealthy missions to intentse all-out warfare missions. That means that there will be enough diversity over the course of the game to keep you entertained on every mission.
While the game could be longer (single-player is quite short), there is still quality to get. The characters, while not the best ones either, are memorable enough so that you'll actually recognise them throughout the different missions. The story itself is mostly military-missions showing the grittyness and hostility of the location soldiers are sent to these days.

Combat itself is pretty straightforward. There is nothing revolutionary, which means that you if you've played Battlefield or any other shooter, you have also played the mechanics of this game. However, those mechanics definetely still work, and it is the different range of missions, locations and intensity that will keep you entertained throughout the game.

The music of this game is beautifully composed bu Ramin Djawadi (Game of Thrones). The music really helps the story to be told throughout the game. The graphics are also nice to look at. The locations you play in all have their unique colours and feeling.

Overall I do really recommend this game. It serves a more realistic approach (while probably still a little over-the-top) to the shooter-games, and it kept me entertained throughout the whole story.

reviewText: This game wasn't bad, but there isn't enough content to warrant spending any more than about $5. Still, there is some fun to be had; the sliding and stabbing mechanics can make you feel pretty bad**s and headshots reward you with a satisfying splat. The shooting mechanics are fine and the graphics are pretty good (some scenes of the mountains are actually breathtaking) but that's where the good ends really.The campaign is kind of cool because it feels a bit like you're playing the movie Lone Survivor" but it's far too short - like mayyybbe five hours. The characters and story are bland and I couldn't make myself care about any of it which is unfortunate given that this game is supposed to represent a real
date: ongoing conflict that involves many real people. The AI is terrible and each gunfight devolves into waiting for each individual head to pop out from behind cover. The game is glitchy and has little direction as to which rock you have to hide behind to activate the next scripted event. At one point
recommended: I got into a death loop beacause I was killed by a truck rolling into my cover and blowing up only to be spawned directly in front of that very same truck just before it exploded again. I almost exited the game right then but I eventually got out of the loop and found that if you manage to get yourself back to where the enemies spawn
hoursPlayed: they will completely ignore you because you are not where the game expects you to be. It's stuff like this that really ruins what could have been a cool concept for the Medal of Honor reboot. I got this game in a humble bundle so I'm not too worried about value
voteText: but I can't really recommend this game unless you can grab it for $5 or less."

reviewText:
I started playing this game not expecting much.  Then the only reason I continued playing it was just because I could laugh at it.  And then I realized that trying to laugh at it was just making me slowly die inside.  So having finally uninstalled it, here are some of the main things that I find completely ridiculous in this game:

Apparently your character's arms are made of wet spaghetti noodles, because while your squadmates have no trouble lifting their arms above their head and hauling themselves onto a ledge, you have to get one of them to boost you up by running over and pressing a button.
The game shatters all attempts at being taken seriously when it chooses to call these helping hands buddy boosts".

reviewText:
So I purchased this game out of nostalgia for the originals, hoping that at the very least, I would get a good 5-10 hours of a mindless linear shooter campaign in which i could unwind by popping skulls, and half paying attention to an unoriginal story.
Unfortunately, it appears that even though my standards were very low, I still set my expectations much too high.  The level design is rather convuluted, and I often found myself trying to figure out where to go.  I guess this shouldn't have been as much of a problem as a lot of the level progression is explained to you by your squad mates.  Unfortunately, for the majority of the game, the entirety of the Dialog was both imperceptable and unitelligable, leaving me feeling lost and confused.
On 3 or 4 occasions, the game got stuck, and failed to load the next mission objective, leaving me confused and frustrated for a few minutes until I figured out what was going on, and re-loaded the game save.
Unfortunately, not even the story was able to redeem this game in my eyes.  Unlike most linear first person shooters, Medal of Honor doesn't try to tell some kind of story with a villan and a hero via dialog and cut scenes, but rather it attempts to give the player a slice of life experience".  This is all well and good
date: however it was not executed well.  As most FPS characters are
recommended: the subjects of this game are static characters who neither develop as the game goes on
hoursPlayed: or are given a chance to really set themselves apart as someone for you to care about.  And since you don't care about the characters
voteText: you unfortunately are left not caring about what happens to them
helpfulPercent: causing the "slice of life" arc to fall on deaf ears
votesHelpful: and a regretful wallet."

reviewText:
Medal Of Honor (2010) a corridor shooter. You follow your squadmates through linear environments, and click on taliban to kill them.

It's a pretty game, but there's just no substance. It tries to stress the importance of keeping each other alive, but your teammates are invincible, friendly fire has no effect, and your fellow soldiers frankly don't give a damn about you outside of scripted sequences. They can have a perfect shot directly behind someone who is blasting AK rounds at you, and they will often not bother taking it. To be honest, they're more or less entirely useless outside of cutscenes and scripted sequences, only serving as voices telling you what and what not to do, or time wasters you need to wait for before you can progress into the next area. Seldom does the game even allow you to move ahead of them - one of the few times it allowed me to, doing so triggered a glitch that prevented the game from progressing until I reset to the last checkpoint.

About the only helpful thing your teammates do for you is give you ammo when you stand next to them and press F"

recommended: but often what they do give you are hundreds (in one case up to a thousand) of rounds at a time. As long as you're using weapons they have the right sort of ammo for in their pocket munitions factory
hoursPlayed: you will never run dry. This sort of undercuts the tension when you're supposed to be completely isolated and on your own in hostile territory.\n\nThe game tries to mix things up with sections where you must SOFLAM target something to call in airstrikes

There are also stationary sniper sequences that are more "Where's Waldo?" then the standard shooting range stroll.\n\nEverything is unrelentingly guided. This is evident from the very first scene

reviewText:
I never really thought that Medal of Honor would ever get my attention. I always thought it was just another top-notch military shooter with a stupid villain and a world consuming problem (COD, Battlefield 3). It's a military shooter yea, but the game doesn't serve you a stupid story with completely forgettablte characters. In Medal of Honor you embark on intense missions against the Talibans over the course of 3 days. You play as several characters instead of only one. Missions after missions the pace is kept to a comfortable level ranging from stealthy missions to intentse all-out warfare missions. That means that there will be enough diversity over the course of the game to keep you entertained on every mission.
While the game could be longer (single-player is quite short), there is still quality to get. The characters, while not the best ones either, are memorable enough so that you'll actually recognise them throughout the different missions. The story itself is mostly military-missions showing the grittyness and hostility of the location soldiers are sent to these days.

Combat itself is pretty straightforward. There is nothing revolutionary, which means that you if you've played Battlefield or any other shooter, you have also played the mechanics of this game. However, those mechanics definetely still work, and it is the different range of missions, locations and intensity that will keep you entertained throughout the game.

The music of this game is beautifully composed bu Ramin Djawadi (Game of Thrones). The music really helps the story to be told throughout the game. The graphics are also nice to look at. The locations you play in all have their unique colours and feeling.

Overall I do really recommend this game. It serves a more realistic approach (while probably still a little over-the-top) to the shooter-games, and it kept me entertained throughout the whole story.

reviewText: This game wasn't bad, but there isn't enough content to warrant spending any more than about $5. Still, there is some fun to be had; the sliding and stabbing mechanics can make you feel pretty bad**s and headshots reward you with a satisfying splat. The shooting mechanics are fine and the graphics are pretty good (some scenes of the mountains are actually breathtaking) but that's where the good ends really.The campaign is kind of cool because it feels a bit like you're playing the movie Lone Survivor" but it's far too short - like mayyybbe five hours. The characters and story are bland and I couldn't make myself care about any of it which is unfortunate given that this game is supposed to represent a real
date: ongoing conflict that involves many real people. The AI is terrible and each gunfight devolves into waiting for each individual head to pop out from behind cover. The game is glitchy and has little direction as to which rock you have to hide behind to activate the next scripted event. At one point
recommended: I got into a death loop beacause I was killed by a truck rolling into my cover and blowing up only to be spawned directly in front of that very same truck just before it exploded again. I almost exited the game right then but I eventually got out of the loop and found that if you manage to get yourself back to where the enemies spawn
hoursPlayed: they will completely ignore you because you are not where the game expects you to be. It's stuff like this that really ruins what could have been a cool concept for the Medal of Honor reboot. I got this game in a humble bundle so I'm not too worried about value
voteText: but I can't really recommend this game unless you can grab it for $5 or less."

reviewText: Medal of Honor can be compared mostly to the recent episodes of the Call of Duty franchise. You get a military shooter with very linear and short campaign and a multiplayer mode which was designed for the masses. In both parts MoH fails to compete against the successful series. However, there are some parts which are more valuable than in the case of the other. I played through the game twice, so it can be considered as one of my favorite military shooters to date.\n\nI would start with the graphics and overall design. Unlike Warfighter, MoH uses the Unreal Engine which is a good choice for any shooters. The utilization however is not the best. The game has the usual previous generation console issues" like blurry textures

reviewText: Making somebody sign up for an EA account to play online after they already have an account with Steam? I thought we were past this. Anyway, the single player is linear, with checkpoints guiding you down the corridor from point A to point B while shooting bad guys". The plot attempts fails to draw emotions while simultaneously keeping you from caring about anything in the "story". Medal of Honor offers nothing that hadn't been seen before; it consists of mindless killing without anything to care about. It's a game that doesn't make you think. Yes its made by EA, yes it uses Dice, This is not an excuse though.   Maybe the Campaign is fun, I havent tried it but the online game play is just nothing but chatoic spawn killing and camping. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
You're a Tier One operator, you're on active duty in Afghanistan and your name is... Rabbit?

This Medal of Honor game reeks of Call of Duty influence, except sadly the gameplay isn't as fluid as Call of Duty's and the campaign isn't as interesting either. Down to the stupid player character names (Rabbit = Soap anyone?), it's clear EA tried to revive a classic series and bring it back to life to compete with the big boys. Unfortunately, they failed and we're left with a generic FPS game set in the brown 'n' bloom desert. With an unengaging plot which tries too hard with it's cutscenes, there's little to push you to press forward in the campaign.

Enemy AI is garbage too, leading to mostly dull fights in the streets, rooftops and warehouses of Afghanistan. The guns look nice, and feel good to shoot. They even sound nice. It's just a shame they're stuck in this game. Graphics can be appealing at times but mostly the dull uninspired enviroments leave a lot to be desired, and the lack of graphics options in the main menu was a let down as I had no way to reduce the jaggies which soured my experience a little.

In conclusion, EA tried to create a Call of Duty killer yet only managed to spawn a generic, drab, uninspired FPS set in the desert which spells boring enviroments -a-palooza and tries to pull you in with a cliché and boring story. Avoid.

reviewText: I got this game in a bundle a while back. The campaign is short, enjoyable and cinematic. The story follows several squads participating in the same mission, and switches between them as necessary. I found that to be a nice touch, and I am glad they didn't try to cram in some lame supervillain plot, instead setting it in the middle east. Gameplay is solid if unspectacular, pretty standard more-or-less-on-rails military shooter stuff. There's never any real doubt (or choice) about where to go or what to do. Graphics, music, sfx - all pretty solid. Decent voice acting.\n\nOverall, though I never really found the experience particularly engaging, I did enjoy it while it lasted, so it gets a recommendation from me.

reviewText: This game is a decent game. It has pretty grafix and it runs decently. It's worth picking it up on a sale to experience the mediocre but enjoyable story. This is the perfect Call of Duty clone. It wants to be Modern Warfare so bad it's not even funny. Down to the smallest detail. If I have one complaint about the Singleplayer is that it's sensitivity option is PURE ♥♥♥♥♥! It doesn't go low enough. I've lowered the DPI on my mouse and it still goes WAY faster than I would like to. It's such a basic option, yet they didn't fiddle enough with it so it makes the game kinda unplayable for me, I had to pull every trick in the hat, lower Windows sensitivity and so on so forth, to make it playable. Every game's sensitivity option should go from 0 to 100. 0 being DEAD STOP, not moving at all, 100 being crazy fast. Not this game. This game is special.... This is even more curios because the MULTIPLAYER's sensitivity option is very good. It does what it's supposed to do, it goes as low as you want it to, until it stops moving completely. Weird. So this nice segway brings us to multiplayer. If you're buying it for the MP, DON'T. Get the latest COD, it'll be the same. At the time of writing there are only about 100 players playing the MP at any given time! Only a couple of the 4-5 MP modes are played, and those are not the best kind of modes. Not to mention that those 100 players, given their dedication, are MAX level and have every little ♥♥♥♥ unlocked, so they're like 5 times more powerful than you, due to the better upgrades they have. If you want a compelling MP experience similar to this go play COD, or try your luck with Medal Of Honor Warfighter, but even with Warfighter I don't think the MP community is what it was at launch, not that this game even EVER had a decent MP community, not even at launch. So bottom line is, buy this game at a sale to experience the decent Singleplayer campaign. That is all.

reviewText:
I don't understand why this game was not better received.  This game is bonafied proof that video game design is a fully developed artform.  Not since Goldeneye I found myself so accidentally emotionally involved in a game.
I was 3/4 of the way through before i realized how well the music coexisted with the action, in a subtle but very real way.  And when the apaches swooped in to save you after desperately fighting off the enemy, wow, almost drew tears I was that relieved.

Don't get me wrong, its nothing new graphically, but in terms of realism I think it has something that other games can't even touch.  Can't wait for the next installment.  I will buy it on release day (instead of waiting nearly a year to pick it up like this one).  Honestly, the most surprisingly good game I have played in a very long time.

Must Play!

reviewText:
7/10 AN AMAZING STORY BUT NOT MUCH AFTERWARDS

PROS:
-beautiful graphics
-supports ultrawide monitors natively
-amazing campaign
-short campaign (depends on your point of view)

CONS:
-no graphics options
-first EA game to introduce online passes (little known fact)
-short campaign (depends on your point of view)
-no replay value

MY PERSONAL OPINION (READ IT IF YOU CAN SPARE THE TIME!)
Medal of honor is a game that looks beautiful and tells an amazing story. from beginning to end it was an enjoyable experience that left me wanting more at the end. little known fact about the game is that it was the very first EA game that utilized the online pass" concept requiring you to purchase the game brand new in order for the multiplayer to be available. if the game was purchased pre owned then a pass had to be bought at 10 dollars if you wanted to play multiplayer. i personally played the multiplayer on XBOX 360 after they scrapped the idea and it was a very enjoyable experience. its too bad that the game had it however because due to it the games online multiplayer never thrived the way it could have
date: especially since it was competing against call of duty.all in all
recommended: the campaign is short but worth it. if it goes on sale i highly recommend it. for the 2.99 i got it for i couldnt have asked for a better game. its a mighty shame that medal of honor never got the exposure it deserved and got the shaft for the more preffered battlefied franchise. maybe one day medal of honor will rise once more."

reviewText:
I think this was a great game, but there were a few problems with it.

Pros:
Good storyline
Interactive gameplay
Hitboxes aren't messed up
20+ weapons at your disposal

Cons:
Graphics aren't amazing, but they're good
Very short campaign (took me about 3.5 hours to finish it)
A few glitched areas
No graphics changing settings (I looked, but I didn't find any)

This game doesn't require an amazing computer to run (My 500 dollar computer runs it fine). Overall, it's a good game for the price. I got it on Humble Bundle, but it's easily worth 20 dollars. No more though. ( assuming it comes with multiplayer)
The multiplayer is the same as COD or CSGO; filled with hackers and (wanna-be) trolls. It's fine, but I much prefer the campaign mode. If you're looking for a casual shooter to spend some time on, you should get this. But if you expect an abnormal amount from your games, prob not. 3.8/5 Would reccomend to anyone who enjoys casual shooters.

reviewText: The story campaign of MoH takes about 5 hours or less. While it starts off strong and is less over the top and more realistic than Call of Duty, it also feels tone deaf and starts to meander toward the end, eventually just throwing sheer numbers at you until you explode your way to a confusing and unsatisfying outro. There were more than a few glitches in the scripting that would have me loading past checkpoints because I hit an apparent dead end or endlessly respawning enemies with no chance of progress. On the reset eventually a cinematic event would start that never happened the first or second or time around that would unlock the next part of the map or start a cutscene. There's a stealthy sort of mission halfway through that would not let me get the drop on the bad guys quietly from any approach. The game itself would crash every other time I started it up and a couple of times in-game. I didn't touch the Tier 1" mode or multiplayer but I'm guessing that's not as fun as CoD
date: either. (Plus I didn't feel like setting up yet another exclusive game account so EA can track my stats.)"

reviewText:
Yeah, this game is..... crappy.

Surprinsly sub-par for when it was released.
The campaign is glitchy and poorly planned. There were a number of times when I had no idea what to do. (Shameful really because in a game like this its usually just a matter of pointing out which direction to shoot in.)

The _feel_ of the game is wrong. Guns are too accurate and aren't rewarding to shoot. Compare this game to Battlefield 3 or hell even Modern Warfare 2 and the guns just feel *fake*. (Yeah I know they _are_ fake). As I was playing the game I had the distinict feeling that it was made without passion. I stopped after a few levels and found better ways to spend my time.

I don't recommend, just go buy Battlefield.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely forgettable and a prime example of what happened to the FPS Genre: No immersion, barely any story, no atmosphere, embarrassing AI and scripted event after scripted event.

It tosses literally hundreds of enemies at you hoping you won’t realize what linear mess you are actually playing. The biggest irony is that even though it has action up the bum you’ll get bored very quickly and catch yourself thinking “When is this game is going to end?”.

To top it all off the campaign is barely 5 hours long on medium difficulty. This game is nothing but a big tainted stain on a once magnificent gameseries and should be avoided by everyone!

reviewText:
Singleplayer: Terrible.
This turns from a hand-held corridor shooter to an on rails shooter to turret sections several times and none of them are really fun. There is no real story, just loads of US Armed Forces and gun wanking. You are pushed from one set piece to the next without any clear goal and mow down thousands of troops (seriously, if you don't move on certain bits stuff just keeps spawning in endlessly.)
PC options are laughable and I actually had to google for help on one mission - if you find yourself in a helicopter turret section and the annoying voice keeps shouting at you to use missiles, just hold down 4. Yes, 4. Totally intuitive and explained in detail, never.
This seems like a minor, petty dig at it but that's going to be the one thing that will come to my mind when someone mentions Medal of Honor - having to alt+tab out of a game to google for help on its controls. Marvellous.

I'm actually somewhat disappointed I got this in the Humble Bundle because I can't delete it from my Steam Library.

reviewText:
The game seems to be trying to show the realism of war, the bleakness- as the colour palette shows. But the game mechanics prevent it from doing this. Lack of health packs means lack of tension, ammo can be gotten from team mates so the fact that you have limited ammo in your weapons is a bit of an illusion. At many points during the game the music will just stop. One example is during a mission as a character you’ve never played before, you and your three (every level is you and 3 invulnerable team-mates) holding off against waves of insurgents. There’s no music to provide realism and tension! Except there is no tension, the enemies come at you from the same paths again and again, I’ve been playing this character for about 20 minutes, why should I care if he lives or dies. MAKE ME CARE GAME. If the game is relying on the fact that it’s based on real-life events to make me care about the characters then it’s sorely mistaken. The game’s mechanics of what is essentially unlimited ammo, team-mates that absorb whole clips of both enemy and friendly fire, incredibly stupid AI, bullet spongy enemies, extreme linearity and oh much more mean that it cannot in all fairness successfully convey real-life situations and make me feel the horrors of war. Either you go the ARMA route where one bullet can kill you, where the realism of warfare is far more apparent than MoH or you go the CoD route of arcade mayhem while conveying emotions through storytelling. Medal of honour is an absolute mess.
The game is disjointed, horribly disjointed. The story is only carried by the cinematics which bookend levels, if your players need the cinematics to follow the story/care about what is going on then you’ve failed at FPS storytelling. Every few levels you change character, moving from special forces to simply infantry. That’s fine in and of itself, but I actually became slightly disorientated, if you skip the cinematic it can take a few minutes to work out who you are playing as based on your location and team members. Not that you can give any orders to your team mates, even medal of honour European assault let you do that. They just follow scripted events and bark orders at you. The game has predictable scripted sequences that even Activision would laugh at. You see all the Call of duty references? That’s because it’s so ♥♥♥♥ing clear that MoH is EA’ response to call of duty. Now in 2013 it’s obvious that they’ve focused on Battlefield as their counter to CoD, even though the games are very different (multiplayer wise) single player wise they’re both a boring as one another.  But of course, it’s the multiplayer component that sells both games.
Medal of Honor lacks colour, which is part of this aim at ‘realism’- though in the sense of feeling not in gameplay. Its so boring and depressing, which sums up MoH. Not depressing because of its focus on real-life events or questioning the legality and morality of what the soldiers are actually fighting for (which would actually make an interesting twist to modern military shooters) but because it shows complete and utter disregard for originality and the medal of honour franchise. The lack of a HUD reiterates part of this  ‘realistic approach’, yet in a game where you cans till take a handful of bullets before dying it seems like a bit of useless attempt at getting across whatever message about war Danger close are trying to convey.
Forget about the series being set in ww2, even if MoH were set in the second world war, itd still be ♥♥♥♥ing boring. The guns feel boring, and the enemies are not interesting in the slightest. They’re just Nazis in middle-eastern garb. By that I mean they have no character outside of them being EVIL. We don’t see anything that makes us question why we are killing hundreds of these guys, it’s like the game just paints the word TERRORIST in great big letters on their heads. That’s all the motivation we need apparently. Maybe that’s a joke at how soldiers have to remove those thoughts from their heads in order to do their job properly. Or it’s just lazy storytelling, you pick.
Graphically this game looks about 3 years older than it should. 2011 was only a year away which would herald the use of the frostbite 2 engine. Even battlefield bad company 2 looked far superior to Medal of honour and that came out the same bloody year. The only decent textures are on people’s faces, everything else oozes muddy brown pixels. I’d argue that this is due to an attempt at making a console beating CoD killer, but EA must have been utterly delusional to think that. If CoD gets complaints for being stale then MoH is a loaf of bread left behind two biscuit tins for 4 years, dusted off and then put in shiny packaging to sell to people who only want call of duty clones. Not that it can even be called a clone; the changes it does make (aside from the MoH ability to lean around cover) make the game into a boring mess. Oh and the bugs, these mainly revolve around the AI and the ragdoll/physics effects, at least they make me laugh I guess, something in this game has to.

The studio behind this game have an interesting history, as EA Los Angeles they created the battle for middle earth games, all MoH games from Frontline and created both red alert 3 and the terrible ending to Command & Conquer, tiberian twilight. A history of some great and some terrible games. Rebranded as ‘Danger Close’ the studio made the two modern Medal of Honour games, the last of which has been classed as a franchise killer. Now EA have rebranded the studio yet again as DICE Los Angeles, and set them to work on the extremely anticipated game, Battlefront 3. I really hope danger close rethink their fps game design. Clearly modern military shooters were not a genre the studio was good at, taking tons of tropes and clichés, covering it in cardboard and serving it on a grey plate in a grey room for grey people to sit and eat while they laugh at re-runs of Miranda.
That all said, Battlefront 3 is being designed by the DICE team behind Battlefield, so hopefully Danger Close, I mean DICE LA, won’t be able to suck the life out of this one.

reviewText: Pretty damn fun game with excellent grafx!  Game was kinda short just under 5 hours, but it was enjoyable.  I was sucked into the story which revolves around a US Ranger team that pwnz and gets pwn3d.  As the story unravels you'll find yourself being emmersed in it and don't wanna stop and you just can't wait to see what happens next.  Not a bad game and very much worth the play.  If you've played CoD's SP campaign this one probably isn't much different.  Oh, and it has MP, but I skipped it and went on to my next game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Medal of Honor is another game in the growing list of drudgingly boring modern military shooters. The level design is bland and uninspired, the gameplay is boring and monotonous, and frankly, the game is overall rather broken. I played through the first handful of missions on hard mode, running around without regard for my character's well-being, avoiding cover and simply rushing my enemies. Also, I was using the pistol the entire time (Imagine the style one would play older shoot-em-up type games, like Doom; that's how terrible the AI is) This got me through completely fine, and the only time I died was when one of my computer controlled allies threw a grenade at me and ultimately killed me.\n\nAddendum, this game is not very good. Unless you are into modern military shooters with very simple objectives and straightforward gameplay, then this game is not for you.

reviewText:
Disclaimer* I'm a US Army Operation Iraq Freedom 2 VET

Realistic FPS that doesn't focus on scores but on the experience. From beginning to end it felt like I was in a movie with it's seamless cutscenes, and ability to slide directly into each mission. Fun to play and also theraputic if you are an OEF/OIF vet. P.S. The mission where you defend the blown up house stressed me out so much I stopped playing and came back two weeks later to finish it. In my opinion

(OUTDATED): I'm sorry, but this game is a disappointment. I was expecting more out of this game. (UPDATE AS OF 6/28/2014): At first I was disappointed with this game back in 2012 until one of my friends urged me to play it. After jumping into the game, I realized what a mistake I made by not giving this a chance back in 2012. First off, it's a WAY better game than Bad Company 2, and it's a very solid title. My only issue however are the campers since there's a lot of them.

But other than that, it's a great game and I totally recommend it.

reviewText: Having gone into this game with the notion that it would be just like all the other fps campaigns out there , bland ,on the rails and without a good story I must say I was pleasently surprised! I Highly enjoyed the game the characters in the gamae work well and are actualy useful , they will kill enemies give you ammo and point out enemies to you rather than being useless bullet soakers like in other shooters.I also commplement the fact that stealth sections areent forced on you, you can make up for a mistake rather than being condemened to an instant death or loss. The gunplay worked reasonably well and although there is definatly alot to be desired the headshot system is Very satisfying. Finaly I'd like to say that unlike every other fps I have played, (other than halo of course) this ending actualy kind of made me feel sad. I would recommened this although of course it does have it's flaws in the end I found it to be quite the enjoyable campaign, I'd give it a 7/10 as far as its genre is concerned but as a whole a 6/10 is more fitting
